speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am happy to have an opportunity to discuss the health aspects of the issues raised by Bill C-226, namely the continued use of the manganese containing gasoline additive MMT, or its substitution.
Our experience with lead additives showed how a seemingly unimportant decision to use a specific additive can have far-reaching health consequences. The ultimate gasoline additive is one that is appropriate both technically and from a health and environmental point of view.
MMT was introduced into the Canadian and U.S. markets in the mid-1970s for use as an octane booster in both leaded and unleaded gasoline. In 1978 the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency banned its use in unleaded gasoline for reasons unrelated to health.
It had been found to slightly reduce the efficiency of the catalytic converters then available for vehicles running on unleaded fuel. At that time there was no concern
about possible adverse health effects and it has continued to be used in leaded gasoline in the United States.
Also in 1978 Health and Welfare Canada conducted an assessment of the potential health hazards of MMT and its products of combustion, manganese oxides. It was concluded that the expected increase of airborne manganese due to MMT under worse case conditions would not be a hazard to health based on the evidence available at that particular time.
In 1985 the Royal Society of Canada's commission on lead re-examined the health implications of increased manganese oxides from MMT with the then proposed phase out of lead additives. The commission noted that the increase in intake via inhalation was small even by comparison to intake from other sources of manganese, and was minute by comparison to intake from food. There was a wide margin of safety between the small extra intake due to MMT and any adverse effects on the nervous system noted in animal or in human studies.
National Health and Welfare has continued to assess MMT and monitors any new information on exposure and health effects. The recent application in 1990-91 by the manufacturer of MMT to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency for permission to reintroduce MMT into the unleaded gasoline was rejected, again because of concerns about conflicting data on hydrocarbon emission increases and catalyst deterioration. Health issues and concerns were not cited as the reason for the decision.
Much of this concern is rooted in the fear that because manganese is another heavy metal like lead, use of manganese could lead to a repeat of the same kinds of contamination and health problems associated with leaded gasoline additives.
Airborne lead from gasoline combustion was a major source of exposure for young children. The majority of daily intake was indirectly attributable to airborne lead and was due to the lead deposited near roadways, on the

November 23, 1992
Private Members' Business
soil and the plants in urban areas. This point has been raised as a potential concern with manganese. However, unlike lead, manganese is abundant in soil and is naturally present in high amounts, several hundred times the amount deposited by combustion of gasoline containing MMT. In addition, ingested manganese appears to be well handled by the human body.
There are some critical differences between lead and manganese. Manganese is an essential element, required in fairly large amounts every day to maintain our health. This means that there is a threshold below which there will not be any toxicity, and we do not have the same concerns about exposure to trace amounts in the environment.
Manganese intake, metabolism and excretion are generally efficiently controlled by the body, and manganese is not stored for many years in the body in the way observed with lead.
In contrast, lead has no known biological function. It is a general cell poison. It is highly toxic at extremely low dosages. In the last 20 years we have witnessed a continual lowering of the blood lead level considered to be a health concern for children.
At very high doses manganese like lead is a severe neurotoxin. The question for us today is, how high is too high? In miners, smelter workers, those exposed to
50,000	or more times the normal air levels of manganese, mental disturbances, slow clumsy body movements, speech disturbances and muscle rigidity similar to Parkinson's disease, have been cited. This is a condition called manganism. Somewhat lower levels, around one milligram per cubic metre, have resulted in the first signs of brain damage, including fatigue and hand tremors in exposed smelter workers. Since typical air concentrations in Canadian cities are about 20,000 times lower than this, 0.04 micrograms per cubic metre, neurological damage is not a health effect of concern at normal levels. This conclusion is supported by the U.S. Public Health Service in a 1991 report.
There are, on the other hand, some important differences between lead and manganese which decrease our certainty about the effects of manganese. While lead appears to be equally toxic whether ingested in food or inhaled from air, manganese appears to be much more toxic when inhaled. This has created a lot of concern and has also led some people to discount the information on
safe levels of intake gained from ingestion studies. Too much manganese is toxic, regardless of its route of entry into the body.
We are all exposed to manganese in both air and food. Under normal circumstances, as in most Canadian cities, airborne manganese is extremely low, and we breathe in about a microgram of manganese each day from the air. On the other hand, we take in somewhere between 2,000 and 9,000 micrograms per day from our food. Absorption is very much higher via the lungs than it is via the gastrointestinal tract, probably between 10 and 30 times higher. But the amount to which we are exposed via air is so much lower that the effects of increased lung absorption are really wiped out. Therefore it is extremely unlikely that the small amount taken in by inhalation is going to have any measurable effect.
Special groups in the population who take up more manganese on a body weight basis than most include infants, youngsters, pregnant women, people who are anaemic, or have calcium, protein or other deficiencies. In these cases the contribution for inhalation is really dwarfed by the contribution from food.
Infants and children have been singled out as a particular risk for manganese because of their undeveloped metabolic processes which allow about 100 per cent absorption and zero per cent excretion for the first few weeks of life. This is a normal pattern and MMT derived manganese would be a very small portion of the total. There is no evidence that this group is particularly susceptible to brain damage from manganese, unlike the case with lead.
The elderly may be susceptible to this type of damage but we lack the knowledge about both susceptibility and differences in metabolism in this particular group.
In conclusion, our experience has shown us that there are not too many health effects at this particular point in time. I would like to recommend that this bill not be supported at this particular time. There is no need from a health perspective to phase out MMT and replace it.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to take part in today's debate on Bill C-226, an act to reduce automotive pollution. I would like to commend my hon. colleague, the member for Lambton-Middlesex for initiating this private members' bill, which I believe is deserving of the support of this House.
November 23, 1992

The Liberal Party has consistently supported the need for Canada to develop alternative fuels instead of relying solely upon non-renewable fossil fuels. In 1984, the then Liberal Minister of Agriculture, the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex, the same individual who is sponsoring today's bill, stated: "The federal government supported alternative energy sources and was prepared to implement a program for the development of ethanol blended fuels in Canada".
In addition, on April 17, 1991 the Leader of the Official Opposition called upon the federal government to introduce legislation to support the use of ethanol and ban the gasoline additive referred to as MMT. The hon. member also indicated his personal support for a 3.2 per cent oxygen content in Canadian gasoline.
Bill C-226 is designed to reduce pollutants that are released into our environment by automobiles. To accomplish this reduction, clause 3 of the bill would prohibit the sale, importation or production in Canada of any gasoline that had an oxygen content of less than 3.2 per cent by weight and contained the substance MMT.
Increasing the oxygen content will make gasoline burn cleaner as it causes a reduction in carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide while also reducing other organic substances or residues. In addition, by eliminating MMT, a danger to public health would be removed from our atmosphere. MMT is believed to mix with blood in humans and attack brain cells when absorbed into the respiratory system. With evidence suggesting that MMT poses a health risk, I am sure many Canadians would like to see it banned in Canada.
Since 1978 MMT has been banned in the United States. MMT is a suspected neurotoxin that is believed to lead to diseases such as Parkinson's. In addition, the use of MMT in our gasolines increases hydrocarbon emissions by up to 27 per cent. Clearly we can do without MMT in Canada.
We can get rid of MMT and also obtain a 3.2 per cent oxygen content in our gasoline. By using a 10 per cent ethanol blended gasoline we can significantly reduce CO, CO2 and Nox emissions. A 10 per cent ethanol blend would reduce carbon monoxide by 25 per cent, carbon dioxide by 5.9 per cent, nitrous oxide by 5.7 per
Private Members' Business
cent volatile organic compounds by 8.5 per cent and ground level ozone by 5.3 per cent.
Aside from eliminating a significant amount of pollutants from the air and removing MMT, there are other advantages to be obtained by using a 10 per cent ethanol blended gasoline. By blending we can help conserve our non-renewable sources of fossil fuels. In addition, as fuel ethanol is manufactured from renewable biological feedstock such as corn, barley and wheat, the supply is virtually unlimited.
Another major point concerns the present economic difficulties facing Canadian grain growers. With historically low prices for their crops farmers would certainly welcome the market ethanol would provide. With producers experiencing problems with marketing their grains at prices which meet their production costs, an increase in demand for ethanol would be financially beneficial for farmers.
In my riding of Stormont-Dundas a considerable amount of interest and work went toward the establishment of an ethanol plant in Ingleside. I certainly want to congratulate the Seaway Valley Farmers Energy Co-operative for its work in trying to create a grain fed ethanol plant.
I also want to recognize and commend Mr. John Cleary, MPP for Cornwall, and Mr. Noble Villeneuve, MPP for SDG and East Grenville, for their commitment to this project.
On a related matter there is a hope, as Ontario corn farmers face the worst harvest conditions experienced in 20 years, that everything will be done by the federal government to assist farmers in avoiding serious financial problems.
This matter was raised in the House on Friday by my colleague from Prince Edward-Hastings. I hope we will soon see some action taken by the government to help address the cash flow problems of producers who are not able to harvest and sell their corn to meet fall debt obligations.
I believe the government should indicate at the earliest opportunity that it will permit advance payments to be issued for corn left standing in the field under the Advance Payments for Crops Act program and the associated Cash Flow Enhancement Program.

November 23, 1992
Private Members' Business
It is clear that Bill C-226 is attempting to provide cleaner and safer air for Canadians. There is no doubt the reductions in noxious gases and toxins that using ethanol blended gasoline would accomplish. We have an opportunity before us today for this House to give its support to a very worth-while piece of legislation.
I know members opposite are supportive of the environment. In addition, I am aware how the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture is very much in support of ethanol blended gasoline. One cannot pick up a story in the media on ethanol without seeing either the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex or the hon. member for Huron-Bruce pictured in it.
By supporting this bill we can take a step forward for our environment, our health, our farmers, our natural resources and, above all, our future. We can also display once again that Canada is the leader in environmental protection and technology.
It is important for us to remain at the top as it can mean millions for Canada. At present considerable work in the area of biological renewable fuels is being conducted throughout the world. One example is in Germany where a test car has been developed with a rapeseed oil powered engine.
I am pleased to support Bill C-226.1 also recognize its importance in opening up the expanded and highly beneficial use of alternative fuel for Canadians and Canada. Bill C-226 supports our environment and calls for a ban on MMT.
I believe Canadians would appreciate the onus being placed on MMT to prove it is safe rather than for others to say it is not. Nonetheless, MMT is being used without adequate and irrefutable evidence to substantiate that it is indeed safe and therefore should be banned. The time has come to say no to MMT.
In conclusion I want again to commend my hon. colleague from Lambton-Middlesex on this legislation which seeks to make Canadian gasoline the cleanest burning and least polluting in the world. I would like to ask members of this House to give it their support.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the privilege to speak in this Chamber on Bill C-226, an act to reduce automotive pollution.
Before addressing the specific issues of Bill C-226, I would like to say a few words about automotive pollution, what this government has done and, more important, will be doing about automotive pollution.
Automotive pollution is the single biggest factor contributing to the formation of smog in Canadian cities. Under the green plan, this government's comprehensive environmental agenda for tackling Canada's pollution problems, the Minister of Environment announced a $30 million initiative to combat urban smog.
Another initiative will see the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources undertaking measures to initiate a further round of fuel efficiency targets for new vehicles, an important element in the government's plan to stabilize the emissions of greenhouse gases.
Certainly Canada has launched a number of initiatives to limit pollution from motor vehicles. We have eliminated the use of lead additives in gasoline. No longer will we have to worry about the potential threat to health, especially to the health of our young children, that the presence of lead in gasoline posed.
We are currently assessing ways to reduce the sulphur contents of diesel fuel which, when used with more technologically advanced engines, will reduce the emissions of particulate and black smoke emanating from large trucks and buses.
Our standards for the exhaust coming out of the tailpipes of our cars and small trucks are among the most stringent in the world. These standards set strict limits for nitrogen oxides which contribute to acid rain and are key components in the formation of smog. They also set limits on the amount of hydrocarbons, another major contributor to smog that cars can emit, and on carbon monoxide.
On February 20 of this year my colleague, the hon. Minister of Transport, signed a memorandum of understanding with Canadian car manufacturers and with car importers to establish striker standards which will come into effect in 1994.
We are committed to protecting the Canadian environment. We are moving forward on a number of fronts, including a comprehensive agenda to further control pollution from motor vehicles. This includes fuel quality as well as new vehicle emission standards.
November 23, 1992

Bill C-226 has two major purposes. First, the bill would require that all gasoline in Canada contain as a minimum 3.2 per cent of weight oxygen. This minimum percentage effectively favours the use of ethanol over other oxygenates such as methyl tertiary butyl ether, or MTBE. Ethanol is an alcohol that can be derived from grains or biomass. When blended with gasoline it acts as an octane enhancer. Even as I speak, the hon. Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources is making a major announcement in Saskatoon to encourage the production and use of fuel ethanol in Canada.
The environmental benefit of blending ethanol with gasoline is that it leads to reduced emissions of carbon monoxide. Depending on the biomass and processes used for making the ethanol, ethanol may also offer an over-all reduction in carbon dioxide emissions, one of the principal greenhouse gases.
The Canadian government, in its desire of establish a biofuels industry and a level playing field for oxygenated fuels with other alternative fuels such as propane and natural gas, effective April 1 of this year, removed the federal excise tax of 8.5 cents per litre on the ethanol portion of the fuel produced from biomass. The removal of this tax is an incentive for the marketplace to determine the range and extent for the manufacture, use and distribution of these fuels.
Carbon monoxide emissions from motor vehicles are highest during the winter months because it takes longer for the engine and catalytic converter to warm up and function efficiently. In the United States the use of up to
2.7	per cent by weight oxygen in gasoline has been mandated during the four winter months in areas where levels of carbon monoxide exceed the ambient air quality standards.
There is, however, concern that gasoline blends with over 2 per cent by weight oxygen can lead to increases in emissions of nitrogen oxides, thereby contributing to the formation of smog. Smog is a summertime problem in many parts of Canada. Certainly given the initiatives to reduce smog in the United States, this would not be desirable.
Based on these facts Bill C-226 which calls for a minimum 3.2 per cent by weight oxygen in gasoline year round cannot be justified on its environmental benefits.
Private Members' Business
The second part of Bill C-226 calls for a ban on MMT, a manganese additive used in gasoline as an octane enhancer. In Canada the use of MMT as an octane enhancer is allowed in unleaded gasoline up to a maximum of 18 milligrams of manganese per litre. In the United States the use of MMT in unleaded gasoline has not been allowed since 1978, although it continues to be used in leaded gasoline.
The use of MMT in gasoline has been the subject of a number of studies in three major areas: the health effects of manganese released into the environment with combustion, the effect of MMT on hydrocarbon emissions, and the effect of MMT on catalytic converters.
Health and Welfare Canada has concluded that the use of MMT at current levels does not pose a threat to human health. Air quality data has not shown an increase in the concentration of manganese in the air over the last number of years.
A very comprehensive review by the Ethyl Corporation showed that emissions from cars fuelled with gasoline containing MMT have reduced amounts of nitrogen oxides and increased amounts of hydrocarbons when compared to vehicles fuelled with MMT-free gasoline. The emissions met the prevailing tailpipe standards and there was no observable effect on the performance of the catalytic converters.
A less extensive review by the Ford Motor Company shows a much higher increase in the hydrocarbon emissions due to MMT and no reduction in the emissions of nitrogen oxides. Deterioration of the catalytic converters was also observed.
After reviewing both studies, the United States Environmental Protection Agency denied a petition by the Ethyl Corporation to allow the use of MMT as an octane booster in unleaded gasoline but continues to allow its use in leaded gasoline.
It should be recognized that an MMT induced increase in hydrocarbon emissions will become a more important consideration in 1994 when, as mentioned earlier, more stringent vehicle emission standards will come into effect. Generally the government's role is to identify standards to meet environmental quality objectives.
Our intervention to regulate fuel quality should only be where no other mechanism will achieve the desired result, such as our intervention with lead through the

November 23, 1992
Private Members' Business
voluntary co-operative efforts of the fuel suppliers and motor vehicle manufacturers. Specifications for fuel quality are developed to ensure that appropriate fuels are available throughout Canada. This market based approach has proven effective and therefore the government will continue to support and facilitate these efforts.
In closing let me emphasize once more that we cannot support this bill because, first, mandating the use of 3.2 per cent weight oxygen in gasoline year round is not justified on the basis of environmental benefit. The existing data on the effect of MMT on exhaust emissions and catalyst efficiency are inconclusive. According to Health and Welfare's assessment, there is no evidence of any adverse health effects related to the use of MMT in gasoline. The benefits of removing MMT and adding oxygenates to gasoline should be addressed as well as development of a comprehensive strategy on fuel quality. The development of such a strategy should involve fuel producers, engine and vehicle manufacturers and government regulatory and fuel standard setting agencies.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to say a few words this morning on Bill C-226 of the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex. I congratulate him on bringing forward this bill. The operative clauses are fairly simple but the implications for Canadian agriculture, the environment and for health and safety are very large and extensive for our country.
I want to comment on the speeches of the two previous speakers, the member for Calgary Southeast and the member for Parry Sound-Muskoka. The parliamentary secretary has gone into some detail to try to justify the use of MMT in Canadian fuels. Yet it is clear that the United States is not moving away from its ban on MMT.
I have in my hand a document put out by the Department of Health and Human Services from the National Institute of Environmental Health Science in North Carolina, in which the director, Dr. David P. Rail, a physician and a Ph.D., outlines to some extent the very grave concerns that agency had with the use of MMT when it was proposed that it be reinstated. On June 7, 1990 he outlined in some detail the concern about the toxic effects, the absorption effects through the skin and the impact on the central nervous system in great detail.
Clearly the United States is not moving away from the ban it has placed on phasing out MMT.
With regard to the comments by the hon. member for Parry Sound-Muskoka, he mentioned that the minister of energy is making a major statement in Saskatoon this morning. I must say that in my view is totally unacceptable. We have a major piece of legislation before the House this morning. If the minister is going to be making a major statement with regard to the use of ethanol, it should be made in the House of Commons, not at a press conference in Saskatoon. I would hope that when the minister returns to the House he will explain why he did not make the major statement here. This is the Parliament of Canada. This is where statements are supposed to be made on matters that have an effect on our economy, the environment, health and safety and transportation of fuel supplies in this country, not at a press conference in Saskatoon.
On Friday we received a beautiful, thick, glossy booklet put out by the Department of the Environment which outlines programs and activities that the government is involved in. In the section on agriculture there is one page entitled "Sustainable Agriculture". This is the entire content on agriculture in that booklet.
It is interesting to hear government members talking about the importance of moving to sustainable agriculture, the use of ethanol and renewable fuels and so on. However, in this document put out by the Department of the Environment there is not a single mention of the use of ethanol, even though the government did take the initiative of reducing the excise tax 8.2 cents per litre this past spring. We are very appreciative of the government making that initiative, but we have not seen it followed through by other action.
The bill before us this morning, Bill C-226, does principally two things. It requires that gasoline have 3.2 per cent oxygen by weight. The best way to do this is through the use of ethanol. It also removes or bans the use of MMT because of the health concerns that this chemical has caused and the fact that it has been banned in the United States for many years.
The implications of these two actions as proposed in the bill by the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex are very extensive. They reach far beyond those two little clauses in the bill. The impact is on the environment, to
November 23, 1992

reduce the production of carbon dioxide, which has been a major concern and major target in reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect. The impact of banning MMT has wide implications for health in our country. In many areas of the United States they are moving rapidly to eliminate MMT. They are using ethanol and other forms of chemicals as octane enhancers.
The impact of moving to the use of ethanol in our country would be very extensive for agriculture. It is estimated that it would take between five million and eight million tonnes of grain. Whether it was feed wheat in the west or corn in Ontario, the implications of that are very extensive. We only have to look at our largest export markets: some four million or five million tonnes to Russia and the other Russian republics. Therefore, you are talking about something that would be larger in terms of the use of our western grains than any one of our single exports of grain. This of course would have a profound impact on diversification of Canadian agriculture.
I had the opportunity last spring to visit the Lanigan ethanol plant east of Saskatoon. It is a tremendous facility, producing some 10 million litres of ethanol. It utilizes some one million bushels of grain and, at the same time, it uses the material that is left over after the ethanol process has taken place to feed some 15,000 head of cattle. It is a major agriculture diversification facility.
The government should be moving on this immediately. By 1995 it is estimated that we will be importing some
500,000	barrels per day of light crude. Surely if we can replace a large percentage of that with the use of our own ethanol made from our own biomass, but principally grain, feed wheat and com, we should be doing it. The foreign exchange implications are very great.
This bill would achieve all of these things. We hope that the government will move in this direction and that it will adopt this legislation because the impacts would be very great and very useful for our country. This bill would achieve all of these things.
However, there needs to be a commitment by government to more research and development and to reducing the cost of production. There needs to be a public commitment by the government to the use of these fuels because of the impact they will have on agriculture,
Private Members' Business
diversifying our economy and, of course, public health and the environment.
I hope the government will reconsider the position that it has taken here this morning as set out by the two government members who have spoken. The impact could be very beneficial for our country if the government were to adopt Bill C-226 which has been brought forward by the hon. member for Lambton-Middlesex. I certainly hope the government will reconsider and send this bill to committee for analysis and further study, and ultimately for implementation.

speakeroldname: Mr. Len Gustafson (Parliamentary Secretary to Prime Minister):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to say a few words on this bill, particularly as I am a farmer and know of the developments on ethanol in the Lanigan area which the hon. member just mentioned. It is east of Saskatoon where the minister of energy is making a very important announcement today. Our government has removed the taxation on ethanol and taken a very balanced approach to this whole area.
Proposed Bill C-226 would set a minimum allowable content for oxygen in gasoline and ban a manganese gasoline component, MMT, which is currently in widespread use in Canadian unleaded gasoline.
Is this kind of legislation acceptable in Canada? What is the environmental objective of the bill? Is it reasonable to pre-empt a comprehensive review of gasoline specifications and environmental impacts under way in Canada and the United States by pronouncing on one of several possible specification changes?
Federal departments are currently involved in reviewing all aspects of gasoline formulation. Further research on the air quality impacts of oxygenated fuels is required in the context of the examination of changes in several components of gasoline. This is a very complex subject with large potential impacts on the economics of the refining industry, the cost of gasoline, and air quality in urban areas.
The first part of this bill proposes to prohibit the sale in Canada of gasoline that does not contain at least 3.2 per cent oxygen, ostensibly to reduce automotive pollution. This minimum allowable oxygen content could be met using ethanol as a gasoline blending component and might also be met with the use of MTBE, but at higher blending volumes than commonly used for MTBE. However, since over 18 per cent of MTBE is required to meet 3.2 per cent oxygen content, which exceeds the

November 23, 1992
Private Members' Business
amount of MTBE currently allowed, the use of ethanol to meet this oxygen content might be more likely.
A minimum allowable oxygen content of 3.2 per cent in gasoline, therefore, would favour the use of ethanol in an attempt to create a new industry in Canada as well as a secondary market for grains. What will be the effect of requiring this high level of oxygen content in Canadian gasoline?
Oxygenates in gasoline have been found to reduce emissions of carbon monoxide. However, at levels greater than 2 per cent, oxygenates have also been found to increase tailpipe emissions of oxides of nitrogen. These nitrogen oxides react with hydrocarbons to form ground level ozone, a cause of smog.
Depending on how the oxygenates are blended into gasoline, there is also risk of increased hydrocarbons emissions, the other component required for ozone or smog. So depending upon the environmental situation in a given region, such a high level of oxygen content might actually worsen local air quality.
In Canada, high ozone levels and smog are a concern in the lower mainland of British Columbia and in the corridor between Windsor, Ontario and Quebec City and in some regions of Atlantic Canada, at least for part of the year. In these areas some actions have been taken to reduce hydrocarbonate emissions, particularly in the summer months. Forcing such a high oxygenate content into gasoline might worsen the ozone problems, counteracting the results of their programs to date.
Given this situation, mandating that Canadian gasoline contain 3.2 per cent oxygen cannot be justified on environmental grounds.
The U.S. is going through a process of identifying gasoline formulations that give environmental benefits at reasonable costs in their circumstances. Canadians should learn from the U.S. experience and examine the options of gasoline specifications that are available to the refining industry and the provinces, through the established process of the Canadian General Standards Board. Sufficient technical information would be required before the federal government attempts to modify the existing gasoline specification process to address the unique environmental concerns of the various parts of Canada.
The over-all impact on vehicle emissions of a change in gasoline specifications is often not clear, since often the change in gasoline properties will have the effect of reducing some of the vehicle tailpipe emissions while increasing others. Arbitrary specifications which are designed to force the market penetration for ethanol should not be encouraged by supporting Bill C-226. Rather, the established process of considering changes in gasoline formulation through consultation with the vehicle and oil industries and the provincial governments, in conjunction with the Canadian General Standards Board should be followed.
What has the government already done to encourage the use of ethanol as an automotive fuel?
In the February federal budget, the excise tax of 8.5 cents per litre, normally charged on all gasoline sales, has been waived on the content of fuel ethanol produced from biomass. This incentive will offset some of the costs of blending alcohols into gasoline, making it more attractive as a gasoline blending component. Undoubtedly this has been a factor in the recent decision of United Co-operatives of Ontario to begin marketing a gasohol blend in southern Ontario.
In 1990 ethanol-gasoline blends were granted the right to use the Ecologo, under the government's Environmental Choice Program. This program helps promote the use of certain products by increasing consumer awareness of the environmental benefits.
In addition, under the green plan and other government programs, research and development continues to be carried out to reduce the costs of ethanol production so that alcohols can make an even greater contribution to meeting the energy needs of Canadians. A lot of research effort is also directed toward a better understanding of the ways in which transportation fuel formulation can impact on air quality.
We believe that Canada's agricultural industries and the producers of fuel ethanol can take advantage of these initiatives to develop a strong, viable fuel ethanol
November 23, 1992

industry that can significantly contribute to Canada's energy future.
The second element of this bill proposes to prohibit the use of Methylcyclopentadienyl Manganese Tricarbonyl, or MMT for those who prefer using acronyms. MMT additives are one of the options refiners have to increase the octane rating of gasoline. Its big advantage is that it makes a very cost effective contribution to gasoline octane levels, at least at the level at which it is permitted. If MMT were not allowed, gasoline production costs would increase, likely leading to higher gasoline costs to consumers.
MMT has been used as a gasoline component in almost all Canadian motor fuels since 1978. In the United States, MMT was believed to interfere with some of the early automotive exhaust emission control systems and so it is used in lead free gasoline and has been disallowed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency since the 1970s. Its use however continues to be allowed in the U.S. in leaded gasoline.
MMT has undergone extensive assessment in Canada to determine the environmental and health impacts. Although Transport Canada uses gasoline that does not contain MMT in the compliance testing in new vehicles, Environment Canada has tested emissions of vehicles burning MMT containing gasoline and demonstrates that these vehicles were within emission standards.
With regard to the health aspect of MMT, there is no evidence that the use of MMT causes any direct health threat. In fact, manganese is considered to be one of the essential elements of a balanced diet and over 99 per cent of the body's intake of manganese is from a dietary source.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have this opportunity to speak on the bill of my colleague from Lambton-Middlesex, Bill C-226, which would legislate a minimum level of oxygen in gasoline sold across this country at 3.2 per cent by weight and eliminate the use of MMT in gasoline sold in this country.
As I listened to comments made by my colleagues across the floor, once again it reminds me, and I am sure many other Canadians, of what drives the government to its policies of acceptance and rejection of certain legislation proposed either by itself or by us and that seems to
Private Members' Business
be the corporate agenda. Where in the policies of this government do the issues of concern to the people come into being?
I listened to arguments from my colleagues on the government side against passage of Bill C-226. Their argument is that which was put out by the large corporations in this country that might tend to lose something if there was a ban on the use of MMT in gasolines.
I am very concerned about the importance of banning MMT in our gasolines for health reasons. I am very concerned about substituting this octane enhancer MMT by the use of ethanol in our fuels because of its important positive environmental impacts and also the positive impact it would have on the agricultural sector of our country.
I cannot understand how colleagues who understand that there could be even the slightest cause for problems to the health of our nation through the use of MMT in gasoline could object to the elimination of its presence in gasolines at this time.
Last week we listened to reports of how haemophiliacs have suffered because of blood transfusions when a government was warned that a certain procedure could cause complications and the government refused at that time to take adequate necessary measures to countermand that. We see today, the very negative results of that.
Now we hear of another possible threat to the health of Canadians from manganese as it exists in the chemical MMT, a chemical that can cause characteristics similar to lead when absorbed. Manganese is a chemical which is absorbed, and retained. As it is absorbed and retained has an increasing toxicity that can particularly imperil children and the aged in our society.
Manganese is a normal element in the chemistry of the air we breathe and some of the food that we absorb, but when it is absorbed at levels that are too high it does have a toxic reaction. It becomes a neurotoxin and has persistent and irreversible pathological effects on brain structure.

speechtext: The House resumed from Wednesday, November 18, consideration of Bill C-86, an act to amend the Immigration Act and other acts in consequence thereof, as reported (with amendments) from a legislative committee.

Motion No. 9.
That Bill C-86 be amended in Clause 6 by adding immediately
after line 9 at page 17 the following:
"(1.2) Notwithstanding section 10, where a person claims to be a Convention refugee, the person shall, upon request, be granted authorization to engage in employment on completion of the medical examination referred to in subsection (1.1)."

Mr. Speaker, no wonder there is so much cynicism and disdain for politicians in this country when we see what the government has just done in putting another motion of closure on this bill. We have a government that speaks time and again in favour of parliamentary reform and democracy and yet, at the same time, systematically closes down debate on important and controversial bills.
Here we have the most extensive amendment to the Immigration Act since 1976, a bill with 128 sections and 113 pages. Yet at second reading-which by the way it called two days after the bill was tabled-second reading was limited to one and a half days on a closure motion. Now report stage where 69 amendments including 10 new amendments from the government have been tabled has been limited to one and a half days-a short day last
Government Orders
week and one day today-and then the government is limiting third reading to one day tomorrow.
If the government had been reasonable and really did believe in democracy and parliamentary reform and had let this debate run its course, it would have only taken another couple of days. When I was asked by the government House leader and the representatives on the other side, I said that we could have done our amendments on report stage in two full days and probably we would want another full day for third reading.
But no, for all these amendments, for the New Democratic Party's amendments and for our amendments, because it has used up 45 minutes on this closure motion, in effect we really are not even going to get two full days. We got a half day last Wednesday and another half day today.
We are dealing with matters that touch the very heart of this nation. We are dealing with matters that touch on the peace and stability of the whole world. Experts before our committee predict that we will have an increase of three billion in world population in the next 30 years. We now have 20 million refugees in the world and here we are spending a few simple days on these matters when this should involve a lot of discussion and a lot of thought.
I have just come from a meeting at the United Nations. These matters are causing great concern in the United States and in all countries of western Europe: in Germany, in the United Kingdom, in France. They are allowing at least some time to discuss the matter.
Motion No. 9 before us is a Liberal Party amendment dealing with the granting of work permits. Right now, under the present law with the two-stage refugee hearing, a refugee is granted his or her work permit after being recognized at the first stage hearing. Right now it only takes about two months to get to the first stage hearing.
Under the bill before us, there is no provision to grant a work permit to a refugee until the refugee is fully recognized by the Immigration and Refugee Board. In the past this has taken up to two years but now takes between five and six months. But we do not know what might happen with the increased flows of refugees. There is no provision in this bill to provide for the quick

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
and reasonable granting of work permits to refugees after they come into the country. What does this mean?
We had municipalities from Ontario appearing before the committee saying that because the federal government will not grant these work permits quick enough and will not provide for a quick granting of a work permit, many of these people have to rely on welfare. This great number of refugees has to rely on welfare whereas many of them could be working. By the way, many refugees work in the most menial of jobs. They take jobs that many Canadians will not take. But they could be doing that kind of work if we provided for the granting of work permits.
What is suggested in this amendment is that the work permit be granted after the completion of the medical examination. The government has said that the medical examination must take place within 60 days. We are saying in this amendment that we should put into the law that the work permit should be granted after the medical has been completed, which is after 60 days.
The government says that if that is done, people will come to Canada as refugees just to get a work permit within 60 days. What nonsense that people are going to leave Yugoslavia, people are going to leave Bangladesh, people are going to leave countries in central America just to come here and work after 60 days. They are coming because they are legitimate refugees and they are being driven from their countries by violence, by fear, and by persecution.
We should allow these people who want to work, if there are jobs available to them, to work after 60 days, as they can now after the first stage hearing. We support the abolition of the first stage hearing and we believe that the provision to grant the work permit at the end of the first stage hearing is a good thing. However, to leave it open-ended with no provision in the law for the granting of the work permit until the person is fully recognized as a refugee is not only stupid but is inhumane.
In committee the government accepted a certain number of amendments. This is the kind of amendment I thought it would have appreciated and would have agreed to. Under the new system it says that people will
fully complete the process in five or six months, if it is contested. However, that is not assured. That is a hope. What is wrong with putting the provision into the law, such as we done under the present law, that a work permit could be granted after 60 days, after the completion of the medical examination?
As I said, the government agreed to certain amendments in committee and that was good. It showed some reasonableness and the bill was improved in committee. Unfortunately, many oppressive sections still remain and in our amendments before the House we hope to deal with those oppressive sections. This is one of them.
I am now doubtful whether we will even have a chance to debate many of these important amendments coming from the opposition parties. There is this closure motion. It is going to be voted on at 6 o'clock tonight and there are 60 some amendments to deal with. It is totally ridiculous.
I am urging the government to reconsider and accept this amendment or one like it.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to support the amendment that has just been moved by the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace. I wish to add a little to his opening remarks about the shortness of time for this very important debate.
The government put in 70 amendments at almost the last minute before the committee hearings. The government put these 11 amendments in at the very last minute before the deadline last Tuesday. The government knew what it was doing. It told us that it took eight months to prepare this bill before it was tabled in June and then there were two days to study it. Staff lawyers take two weeks to study it and there is only a day and a half for debate.
Committee reading was during the summer when most of the people who could advise committee members were on vacation and when committee members also needed some time with their families. Now after committee hearings there are further amendments from the government and one and a half days to debate the amendments in a long bill-128 pages. It is clear the government does not want to have debate. We will not be able to do justice to the necessary amendments after I, and perhaps other colleagues, have eliminated some of
November 23, 1992

the amendments we originally thought were necessary for the sake of focusing on the more important ones.
This amendment, which would give refugee claimants a chance to work and earn their living within 60 days of their arrival, is extremely important to metropolitan Toronto and the surrounding municipalities. The majority of refugees who have come to Canada are in the Toronto region.
Welfare costs are already very high because Toronto now has higher than average official unemployment, higher than the Canadian average. It is not as high as Newfoundland or Montreal but it is higher than the average for Canada. This has been going on for several years and it has affected welfare costs.
One neighbouring municipality has complained about the number of refugees on welfare even though the numbers are not that great.
In fact, the government is well aware that by putting a cap on the welfare payments it is making it next to impossible for municipalities in Toronto and the region to cover the cost of the refugees whom the government will not allow to work.
Under the new system the government says it take three, four or five months at most until there is a decision. It will not agree to give a work permit at the end of two months because it claims there would be fraud.
I do not understand how the minister can support that with a straight face because he told our committee publicly that the vast majority of refugee claimants are real refugees. Those were the minister's words: "The vast majority are real refugees". In fact he has repeated it.
If the vast majority are refugees how many people are going to travel thousands of miles-whether it is from east, west or south, they do not come across the pole-for what cannot be more than two or three months work at low wages? This is not an attempt to protect the country against a flood of frauds. This is an attempt to punish refugees for being refugees. It is an attempt to punish people who are being persecuted, who are being threatened with persecution, because they have come to seek safety in a country which in the past,
Government Orders
before the last four or five years, earned a great reputation for accepting people in need of protection.
There is no good reason for refusing to let these people work. They want to work. They did not come here to live off welfare. They want to earn their way.
The municipalities want them to work and have said so. The Association of Canadian Municipalities said that to the committee. Yet this government refuses to allow them to work and it can only be because the government is adopting the policy of what is called humane deterrents, as expressed by a previous director of refugee affairs, Raphael Girard. We will not shoot them at the border, we will not send them away without a hearing, but if possible we will make them wish they had never come there by making life miserable with delays and under-funded refugee processing systems and by making it as hard as possible for them to earn a living or to pay for legal help.
This has increasingly become the growing policy of this government. Its refusal in committee to give us any answers to our questions on this point shows it is not willing to listen to reason, unless it has a last minute change of heart now.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first I would like to comment on the amendment and then I will continue in the time remaining to comment on the earlier comments of my colleagues.
In terms of the amendment, the bill does not provide for any specific point at which authorization for a work permit will be given. That is in response to the flexibility that is essential to changing conditions.
There is no question that there has been quite a broad debate on this subject. It is a concern that a number have raised, particularly the municipalities, in terms of access to a work permit.
I think what is important, and I would disagree with my colleague for Trinity-Spadina on this one point, is that a great deal of the refugee sections of this bill are in response to a number of people who were concerned that the process needs to be speeded up to be more humane and to provide for better service for refugees.
The intent of this legislation is to ensure that positive determinations are reached within two or three months, which is essentially the same effect as that of the proposed amendment. What we do not provide for

Government Orders
specifically is that work permits be issued before the determination is found, and the policy will reflect that in the end.
I want to return, if I may, to the comments of my colleagues from Notre-Dame-de-Grace and Trinity- Spadina about the process that we have encountered here. I would like to remind all members of the House that this legislative committee received 186 letters and 116 briefs over a period of four months.
We heard 110 witnesses, 48 groups and 35 officials from federal government departments. Within the community this was widely discussed and a number of meetings were held outside of the committee, both with individual members and with the government.
Therefore, when I hear a complaint on one hand that there were 70 amendments and a comment on the other that the government was not responsive I wonder a little bit about the inconsistency. Most of the government amendments were either technical, in response to very specific concerns raised by witnesses or in response to the opposition.
Certainly, we did not address all of the concerns raised by the opposition or all of the concerns raised by the witnesses. That happens in this process. However, both of my colleagues have said elsewhere that they felt in certain areas that the government was responsive.
The government put forward its amendments when others put forward their amendments, and certainly before the report stage met all its obligations to do so. Its amendments, with one exception, are very technical and make the bill a little bit better.
I too have no sympathy for the process of time allocation. I do not like the process, but on Thursday last we debated Bill C-86 for three hours in this House. We dealt with one quick amendment that took 40 seconds. We dealt with another group of amendments, six amendments, for the rest of the time, one topic.
I spoke-I was the only government member to do so-for eight minutes in this House while successive opposition members trooped in and made speeches that had nothing to do with this bill. That was absolutely their right. However, when I hear the opposition complain
that it does not have time to debate the amendments I worry about those lost three hours and where they went, and how far we might have gotten in discussions on these amendments.
Frankly, I lose a little bit of my concern about time allocation when I am confronted with this indignation this morning and am expected to have some sympathy for that position.

Mr. Speaker, I too want to speak to this amendment because I think it is very typical of what has happened in this country concerning the amendments to the Immigration Act.
There has been some dialogue. The community is very concerned. It is becoming apparent that this government is out of step with the wishes of the vast majority of Canadians, as reflected in this bill and in the amendments it is putting forward.
For example, most Canadians think that family class and assisted relatives should be the priority in immigration, but this bill does not reflect that. Canadians feel that because it has been the history of Canadian immigration. Historically, people can come, and they have relatives here who can assist them in integration into the Canadian community by finding employment, finding housing and dealing with Canadian culture. This bill does not reflect that.
In my community of Surrey North there is a very large immigrant population. There are a large number of Asians from Hong Kong and from some other parts of south-east Asia. In particular, we have a very large Sikh population. The Sikh population has made tremendous contributions to the economic and cultural well-being of Surrey, of British Columbia and of Canada.
We are now downplaying that community's ability to involve its relatives in coming to Canada to strengthen Canada. Those people have extended families and they want extended families to come here.
Similarly immigrants in this country have always had a very high commitment to the work ethic. They have wanted to work from the day they arrived in Canada, like my father when as an immigrant digging ditches in March in Edmonton. He wanted to work and that was the work available.

November 23, 1992

This particular amendment is saying the same thing to refugees. Refugees who have arrived in Canada want very quickly to be able to shift from being a burden on Canada to being a contributor to Canada. They want to be able to get employment so they can support themselves and their families.
We have a government that is not listening to them, not listening to provincial governments that are having to provide income assistance for people who are awaiting the determination of their status and not listening to the general public. The general public says these people are here and while they are here why not allow them to work while their determination is being made? It certainly would be a benefit to the community, to them and to their families.
I cannot agree with the last speaker about the fact that this bill and the amendments put forward by the government have been debated by the public. After the government tabled the bill, there were meetings right across this country of concerned citizens and groups looking at the bill. All of a sudden there are amendments put forward and they have not had the opportunity to study those amendments, to determine whether they meet the concerns raised whether they support them. If the government actually had any faith in its package of amendments, it would let the public look at it at leisure. It would let the public determine whether it could now support the package. I believe the reason the government is now determined to push this bill through is that it knows it would not stand the scrutiny that people would give it if they had a more leisurely opportunity to look at the amendments.
I want to again say that I support this amendment. Most Canadians do. Most Canadians do not agree with the thrust of the government in this bill. They certainly do not agree with the fact that the government will not accept this amendment.

Mr. Speaker, in order to facilitate the debate today I was not going to debate this particular motion. After the government advocate from St. John's, Newfoundland, spoke just a few moments ago I thought that it was only right that we should respond to some of the accusations that were
Government Orders
made in the context of the motion that we are debating today before this House.
There was some discussion, and I agree with my friend from Notre-Dame-de-Grace and my colleague, the member for Trinity-Spadina, what they have said with respect to the rights of people as they enter Canada, either as an immigrant or as a refugee, and their right to work.
First let me make a couple of comments about some very important matters that were dealt with the last time this bill was debated in the House. There were some very, very important amendments proposed by this side of the House, by both the NDP and the Liberal Party, with respect to substantive issues concerning the immigration bill.
We are concerned that time allocation was just announced a short while ago with respect to a discussion on the amendments. Let me just go over four or five of the amendments that we discussed in some detail. There were many people on this side of the House who wanted to continue the debate on matters that concern issues involving family members and their right to come to Canada. One fundamental principle that we stand for in the Liberal Party is uniting family members should they choose to become immigrants or refugees to Canada. That bill was debated. There were members on this side of the House who wanted to continue the debate.
The second motion, No. 5, was a motion on visitors' visas. We all know, as I said on the last day in this House, that visitors' visas were the ones that were causing the most concern with respect to problems with immigration outside of the country for members on both sides of the House about how those visitors' visas were granted. Our proposals were very sound and made sense. The proposals would have facilitated the operation.
The debate was stunted because not enough members were given enough time to make the salient points that they wanted to make with respect to a very vital issue, the visitors' visas that are issued by every embassy in the world. It is not done right. Our recommendations, as proposed by my colleague from Notre-Dame-de-Grace, were substantial and they were recommendations that this government should have taken into consideration and implemented without question. That was debated.

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
Other issues debated were the refund of immigration fees, which was not of much consequence but there were members who wanted to debate that issue, and Motion No. 70, the resident requirements. Along with that, Motion No. 7, proposed by my friend from Trinity-Spa-dina, and Motion No. 6, presented by the member for Scarborough-Rouge River, were substantive issues that this government should have adopted and implemented in this act to make it a more humane and palatable piece of legislation that would guide not only the immigration process in this House but the refugee problem that the government still cannot seem to correct.
The issue before the House now, Motion No. 9, is a motion which we have proposed for the benefit of the municipalities of this country. To put it in its simplest context, its simplest terms, as people come into this country, either by immigration or as refugees, they are denied the opportunity of having a work permit issued immediately.
What we are saying is that as soon as the medical process is through, which takes about 60 days, they should be offered the opportunity to go to work if, because of the economy, a job is available.
Having been offered the opportunity to go to work, at that point, 60 days after their arrival, what does it do? It takes a substantial amount of people who come to this country off of the welfare Rolls. We all know, through the experience not only in Ontario but in Quebec and every other province in this country, that the substantial portion of welfare payments is made through the municipalities. I compliment my friend, the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, for attending all these meetings and for having the perseverance to bring this motion to the House. What we are trying to accomplish is a resolution that will help to eliminate the costly welfare system that we have in our country.
For people who have to apply for welfare, it is picked up proportionately by the provincial government and by the municipal government. If we afford the person more of an opportunity to get to work as soon as he is allowed to come into Canada, it would reduce the welfare rolls substantially, particularly in Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal where over 90 per cent decide to locate when they
become either accepted refugees or immigrants to our country.
This is a motion that is spoken to and presented on behalf of the municipalities of Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal and all the other municipalities right across this country. It goes toward helping them bring under control the very expensive social welfare system that they are forced to fund.

Mr. Speaker, in the time we have I want to focus particularly on three of these motions, Motion No. 10, which would do also for Motions Nos. 12 and 13, and Motions Nos. 11 and 22.
Motion No. 10, along with Motions Nos. 12 and 13, is a motion to remove some offensive words from the bill, offensive in the place where they occur; namely, the words "who there are reasonable grounds to believe''.
What we are talking about is a bill that says if there are reasonable grounds to believe that you have been convicted of something outside of Canada you can be excluded. That is an innovation in our law which obviously suits some police-minded people but does not suit the general public of Canada which believes that a person is innocent until proven guilty.
If the government thinks it has reason to believe that a person has been convicted outside Canada, it has a duty to find out whether that is true, what country it happened in, what court it happened in, where the record of conviction is, rather than say there is a rumour that there has been a conviction of this or that.
It is extremely unjust that a person should be turned away with little or no chance to seriously defend himself or herself simply on suspicion or rumour.
Government Orders
Clause 10 and clause 12 both fail on that point, and clause 13 also.
What I want to have there is that we will deal with persons who have been convicted, or in the case of clause 13, persons who have been convicted outside the country, not persons whom somebody suspects were convicted.
Clause 11 is a little different. Clause 11 would amend page 21 of the bill. I will read a little bit of page 21 to give the context. This is a clause to exclude people on the grounds of their connection with espionage, terrorism or subversion. It is agreed. There was no debate in the committee and I do not think there is any debate here that we need to keep out people who are concerned with espionage, subversion or terrorism. However, what this bill does at this point is to say that we will exclude persons where there are reasonable grounds to believe are or were members of an organization, that there are reasonable grounds to believe is or was engaged in acts of espionage or subversion or terrorism. In other words, it is twice built on rumour: he is, she is or was at some date last year or 20 years or 40 years ago a member of a certain organization or we have reason to think that and we have reason to think that organization, somewhere in the world, 10 years ago, 50 years ago, 1 year ago, it does not matter, was engaged in some of these activities and because this person belongs to that organization, the person will not be admitted to Canada.
What I would like to see changed is that at least the people should be able to know what is the organization or organizations whose members are forbidden to enter Canada. Therefore, I ask that the government prescribe these organizations and say that this, that or other organizations have been engaged in terrorism, or whatever it may be, and any member therefore can be excluded unless there is a catch-all clause at the end and unless the minister says it is all right. However, generally speaking, they will be excluded without much consideration.
Second, I believe the law should say that he or she will be excluded if at the time there is reasonable ground to believe that the person participated in those actions. In other words, a person could be a member of the African National Congress and not have been a participant in all the actions of that congress. A person could be a member of the Republican Party and not have been

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
engaged in the Watergate burglary and so on and so forth. If the tables are turned, a person could be a member of the RCMP and not have been engaged in the crimes that they committed during the 1970s in Canada.
It should be limited to an organization that has been listed as subversive, terrorist or a spy organization and there should be grounds to believe that a person was a member and took part in those actions.
Finally, just a brief word. I want to say that I support strongly Motion No. 22 where it says that we should exclude people because they constitute a serious threat to the security of Canada, not a threat to the security or interests of Canada. Security, yes. If he or she is a threat to the security of Canada, we have to put them out, but if they are a threat to the interest of Canada, that is undefined. Does that mean they are opponents of the Tory government or, if there is a change, opponents of some other government? What are these interests to which the person could be a threat? It is so undefined that a person could not possibly be expected to defend himself against that and therefore it really means that we do not like the colour of that person's eyes or maybe the colour of that person's skin so we call him a threat to our interests.
Those are the only three I wish to speak on and they cover the other two that I have listed here.

Mr. Speaker, I want to speak in particular to amendment No. 22 which was tabled by the Liberal Party and which is being debated in this grouping. Amendment 22 would strike out of article 28 on page 40 the words "threat to the interests of Canada".
Let me explain. That clause of the bill says: "For purposes of section 39 to 40.2, to enable the Government of Canada to fulfil its duty to remove persons who constitute a threat to the security or interests of Canada". In other words, this is a clause in the bill that allows the government to deport people who are a threat to the security and to the interests of Canada.
We in the Liberal Party accept fully the right to deport people who are a threat to the security of the country. That was in the bill we put to the House in the 1970s.
The words "security of the country" are well known. That could be criminality, espionage, terrorism or subversion. Therefore, we believe that people who are a threat to the security of Canada should be deported. In this bill the government has also put in the words "a threat to the interests of Canada". That is not defined. What immigration officers are going to decide if a proposed immigrant is a threat to the interests of Canada?
If somebody appears at our borders or at our embassy abroad and says: "I want to immigrate to Canada", are they going to question them and ask: "Are you against the GST?". Some people in this country and this government think if you are against the GST, you are against the interests of the country. Are they going to ask: "Are you against the North American free trade agreement?" Some people might think if you are against the North American free trade agreement you are against the interests of Canada. Is being against this bill being against the interests of Canada, in the view of some government officials?
The point of the matter is that being against the interests of Canada is not defined. It is too broad and too general. Who is going to make the decision about whether an applicant for immigration is against the interests of Canada and, therefore, should be deported?
In my amendment to the government amendment, I am suggesting that we strike out the words "against the interests of Canada" and simply keep "threat to the security of Canada". We all agree that we do not want people in this country who are against the security of the country. However, we do not want some wishy-washy words in our law that say that we can deport people who are against the interests of Canada and nobody defines what "the interests of Canada" means. It is so general it could mean almost anything to a government in power. It would define what the interests of Canada would be. We do not think that should be in our law.
I am surprised that the government has not gone along with us on this one. I know many people on the government side and I think they would agree with me on this point. However, that is the purport of Motion No. 22.
November 23, 1992

I just want to say a few words on the amendments tabled by my colleague for Trinity-Spadina. As I said a few minutes ago, the Liberal Party fully supports provisions in the law that would keep out of Canada criminals, subversives, terrorists, spies and so on. We support measures along those lines. This bill goes beyond that. This bill provides, for example, that you could be kept out not simply because you have committed a crime but because there are reasonable grounds to believe that you might have committed a crime. That is quite different. Not that you have committed, but reasonable grounds to believe that you have committed. Right now the law says that if you have committed an offence you do not get in. Good enough. Then it goes beyond criminal offences. It goes on to deal with acts or omissions. If in addition you have committed acts or omissions in another country that would be considered criminal offences then you are also barred. My colleague's amendments are attempting to deal with this.
The worst amendments of all are the two catch-all ones that are so broad that they take in almost everything. One is if you belong to an organization that might have committed an offence in the past. He mentioned Exxon.	,
An American may wish to emigrate from the United States. If he or she worked for Exxon, because Exxon was convicted of an environmental offence a few years ago, according to the words of this section they could be barred from admission.
If you belonged to the Republican Party or Greenpeace, in which organizations there have been members who have committed offences over the years, just because they committed an offence or the organization was found guilty of an offence, are you going to bar forever all the other people, who might have been very good people, just because they belonged to an organization which was so structured?
We support those amendments as well. We think the government has drawn the net too widely in trying to keep out people. What is wrong in drawing it so widely is that you end up with subjective decision making, not objective criteria. You end up with unfairness. Whereas one person might get in and not be considered as being against the interest of Canada, another person may be
Government Orders
considered as being against the interests of Canada. There may be reasonable grounds to believe that they belong to an organization that had committed offences. In another case there might not be reasonable grounds.
There is a thin line here that is too vague and will lead to unfairness. It is against the traditions of this country with respect to immigration.
I wish to get back to our own amendment, that we keep the provision that you can deport people who are a threat to the security of the country but we take out the part that says that you should be deported or sent away because you may be against the interest of Canada.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to take the opportunity to respond on this group of amendments. Like my friends across the way, I will tend to do it by referring to Motions Nos. 10, 12 and 13 together, 11 and 22 on their own.
On Motions Nos. 10, 12 and 13, I want to say, and I know that many people in this House recognize it, that the principle of reasonable grounds in criminal activities are well established in this country, not only for the Criminal Code, the tax act and the competition legislation but it is something that requires a well established objective basis.
In the past, the courts quite clearly have made decisions along this line. To suggest that it is simply government responding to rumours would not stand up in any court and would not be reasonable in any government administrative process under Bill C-86 or any other legislation.
In terms of proposal No. 11, it suggests that we would only be able to keep people out that are members of prescribed organizations. In discussing this at length in the legislative committee, one of the expressions I used then which I think is appropriate at this time is that while it is impossible always to know the nature of an immigrant or of a refugee that you might want to bring in in the future, it is equally impossible to be able to know and therefore define all of those people that you are going to want to exclude in the future.
I understand when my colleagues often talk about clauses in legislation which sometimes are too wide open and perhaps cast too broad a net. But I also have come to understand the real problem that we have when we quite clearly start trying to go too far to define. In our attempt

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
to be prudent and fair, we find ourselves in a position where we work against not only the interest of the country but against those who choose to come to the country.
On Motion No. 22, which involves the discussion that my colleague had about the question of the interest of Canada, I want to make two comments if I may. First of all, this particular clause, clause 28 of this bill which will be section 38.1 of the new law when it is in place, is a purpose clause. It provides, as my hon. friend from Notre-Dame-de-Grace has said, for the setting up of sections 39 and 40, which provide for the certification process in recognition that you do not want to have too much power without the proper checks and balances.
This legislation provides for a certification process under the provisions where there is a threat to the country. Both the minister of immigration and the Solicitor General must sign a certificate and that is what this process allows for. Certainly there is protection provided in section 6 of the charter that relates to the same thing.
The second point is that the interests of Canada are not always clearly defined but sometimes they are readily evident. Unfortunately we have seen in this country from time to time those who have come here and co-ordinated or undertaken activities that have nothing to do with things in Canada but with other countries.
For instance, if there was an effort to carry on a plan of terrorism or subversion in another country from Canada it is certainly not a threat to the security of Canada but it is a threat to the interests of Canada.
One thing this particular section of amendments addresses, which is sometimes very difficult for some of us to come to grips with, and I find myself in this bind often, is the question of balance. We constantly must balance the interests of Canada and Canadians with our responsibility to not only provide the opportunity for those who want to come to Canada and contribute to this country but also to provide safe haven and refuge. Certainly in my view that is the greater responsibility that we have.
The balance comes in ensuring that we have a system that is fair, accessible and open and continues to allow Canada to live up to its tradition of being a protector without parallel around the world, while at the same time ensuring the security of Canadians and the immigration refugee determination system by knowing who we have in the process and by being able to deal in those very rare situations with those who should not be in this country. Until now in some cases the minister and the department have not had the ability to remove people from this country when I think any reasonable person would say they should be gone. That is what some of these provisions provide for.
I suppose we could sit and imagine situations where there would be a negative effect, where provisions could, if we examined them in isolation, be used against those who choose to come to Canada. That has not been the tradition in this country. That is not the way the Immigration Act has been used, either the 1976 act or the 1988 act. I do not believe there are many who believe that is about to change.
