speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: The debate will be on all the motions just moved.

Mr. Speaker, I have one motion in this grouping. The other nine or ten are all government motions. I will comment on a couple of the government motions that I think are not merely technicalities. I think they are quite harmful and I regret very much that we were given so little time, on top of everything else, to handle these late government motions after their eight, ten or twelve months of preparation.
First, my Motion No. 14 places a condition on the new powers of the senior immigration officer. On page 25 there is a section, and I will not read it all, that says, after listing certain grounds of inadmissibility:
the senior immigration officer shall allow the person -
That is the person who has just been confronting him.
- to leave Canada forthwith or make an exclusion order against the person.
In other words, he either leaves voluntarily or is ordered to leave.
I wish to add these words:
unless the person requests an inquiry or claims to be a permanent resident, in which case the senior immigration officer shall cause an inquiry to be held concerning the person as soon as is reasonably practicable.
As it stands, the power given to the senior immigration officer is far too absolute, far too arbitrary. There are some things that cannot be cleared up, just standing there, between a person coming in and the immigration officer, even if they are sitting down. The person does not have the time to find out what test he must meet, which was unexpected, and the immigration officer may or may not give him sufficient time, it may not even be practically possible for him to do it. That is why the inquiry system is used.
I am thinking particularly of a person who is a permanent resident but who, in coming back or even after he has come back, may be challenged as not being a permanent resident but a visitor who over-stayed his visa or somebody who came in without a visa, who sneaked in. He may be picked up at his home a day later or a month later and deported without notice as an indirect consequence of this clause and other clauses which the government is about to pass.
Under the new system the person should have a permanent resident card instead of the landing paper. However, there are a couple of problems with that system. The card may expire and if the person has been legitimately abroad working or studying, fully intending to return to Canada, he may be told that he does not have a valid card and is not a resident. The person may have lost the card. It may have been stolen, this can happen. The person may then be told that unless he can
November 23, 1992

prove right on the spot that he is a permanent Canadian resident and he is not a permanent resident he is excluded.
I believe there would be many injustices, perhaps unintentional injustices, in such a case. A person may not be prepared, may not carry around all kinds of documentation with him. If he was robbed of his wallet, and perhaps other documentation was lost as well, they would be available at home in Toronto, or wherever else the person lives, but not available right there while he is standing in front of the senior immigration officer.
There will be other occasions when the person believes that his statement of fact is not properly understood by the immigration officer.
In either case, whether it is a permanent resident or somebody else who believes that he should have the right to inquiry, I believe that this clause should be amended to give him that right to an inquiry before an adjudicator with the time-it should not be instantly then, it could not be instantly then, but it says "within a reasonably practicable time"-to collect whatever evidence this person may have that he is currently a Canadian citizen ordinarily living in Canada but away on business.
For some reason not explained the government is abolishing a very practical arrangement, which is that if a person is leaving Canada to study for a year or something like that and is a permanent resident, a person can get a certificate from the government that certifies that he is a permanent resident and has the right to return. That is the law at present. That provision is being taken away by this bill. It means that the person coming back is very vulnerable to being mistakenly accused of not being a permanent resident. The only recourse against that is that he be allowed to go to an inquiry and have opportunity to present the evidence which would then enable the immigration officers to do justice to his real situation.
I would hope that on further consideration the government would consider this amendment and support it.
There are two other motions I wish to speak on. Motion No. 17, as far as I can understand it-and some of these I have not been able to understand, even with the help of some legal, professional advice-would give this power of exclusion, particularly page 32 which changes the line significantly. Instead of saying that the
Government Orders
senior immigration officer may make a departure order against a person as long as he knows that person is not alleged to be a person described in any other paragraph or somebody who overstayed a visa and was ordered to leave and knows that the person is not the person described.
In other words, if he said it is alleged it is reported, that a certain person should not be let in, the procedure is that the matter would go to inquiry and the person would have the chance to prove that the allegation is mistaken or untrue and that he is not somebody who should be excluded. This subtle little change means instead of saying the person is not alleged to be a person described, it says the person is not the person described. In other words, the senior immigration officer is to make his decision on the spot, not to do a report to an inquiry, but to say leave the country now.
This is a mistake. This is in Motion No. 17, which I will have to oppose for that reason.
Likewise, Motion No. 32 says it is going to strike out certain lines and substitute: "A person who claims to be a convention refugee on or after the day on which this subsection comes into force is not eligible to have the claim determined by the refugee division if (a) the person had, before that date, claimed to be a convention refugee and the person was determined not to have a credible basis for the claim; (b) the person was before that day issued a departure notice; (c) the person has not left Canada since the departure notice was issued".
There have been several refugee claimants who have challenged in courts successfully the denial of their credible basis on the grounds that the test was unreasonably hard at that preliminary stage. This would insist that such a person would be sent away before he has a chance to make the appeal.
That would be very unjust and although this is only transitional from the old system to the new, there are some cases which are in the pipe right now. One of them has already been to court and will go to court further. While it is being decided by the court, and while other cases are being decided by the court, we should not introduce this clause which would send the person out of the country to possible persecution, even death, without the court's having given an opinion on the matter.

Motion No. 40 would allow, not demand, that the officer would be able to put in place a 12-month order
against returning to Canada. This would prevent against going literally from one border station to the other. This is something that does not apply to refugees and is something we have seen the need for in the past.
The amendments to clause 36 provide for more precision and the proposed amendment makes it clearer; before it was a bit loosey-goosey.
I would like to respond very briefly to Motion No. 14 put forward by my friend, the member for Trinity-Spa-dina. He would, I know, agree with me that in terms of dealing with permanent residents and lost cards, there was quite an extensive process of amendments put in place through which the government was responding to very real concerns of the opposition and other people.
Certainly section 23 subsection 4(b)(ii) provides for the protection he seeks. That should be recognized. Again, refugees are quite clearly protected from this section. They are not included in this group. I think that is another important recognition.

Mr. Speaker, as far as the ozone layer is concerned, the situation is serious and indeed urgent.
This year, the ozone layer reached its lowest level in decades and it is deteriorating at a faster rate than
expected. Last month, the ozone layer above Canadian cities reached its lowest level in over 30 years.
This situation, is hazardous to human health. The deterioration of the ozone layer increases the risk of skin cancer and of cataracts that can cause blindness, and it has a disastrous impact on farm production. The health and well-being of Canadians and of the whole world are at stake.
Today, in Copenhagen, nearly 90 countries are trying to accelerate elimination of substances that destroy the ozone layer. I urge the government to take the kind of progressive position the occasion demands and show that Canada is capable of leadership in this field. The government must approve a specific and definitive timeframe for the complete elimination of methyl bromide and commit itself to banning the use of HCFCs. This is imperative, in order to protect human health.

If Canada is to maintain its place as having a leading economy, we must ensure that those students with the desire and ability are able to continue their education.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. At $500 a plate Conservative Party fund raisers the Prime Minister has been bragging about his government's
November 23, 1992

economic policies. He says: "We have got the fundamentals right. We are staying the course".
Yet with unemployment at over 1.5 million and growing, child poverty at 1.1 million and growing, and social assistance recipients at 2.6 million and growing, this is not the sort of progress we need.
For the sake of Canada and their children, will the Prime Minister finally admit his government's mistakes, change course and help make life better for Canadian families, not worse?

speakerposition: Prime Minister
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend refers to unemployment and says it is growing. That statement is false. Then he refers to child poverty and says it is growing. That statement is false as well. The prefatory remarks by my hon. friend are misleading, inaccurate and bear no reflection whatsoever of the latest economic realties.
I have already indicated that the best way we can preserve economic opportunities for our children is to make sure that we do not burden them any further with debts to pay for today's programs. The best way to do that is to increase our productivity, to increase investment, to open new trading opportunities, and to invest in human resources to provide them with appropriate opportunities in the future. That is exactly what we are in the process of doing.

November 23, 1992

Wherefore your petitioners humbly pray and call upon Parliament to pass legislation dealing with the points mentioned, in order to eradicate violence in our society, provide better safeguards for our children and improve the quality of life of everyone in this country.

speakerposition: Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the honour to present a petition signed by several residents of Kingston and other cities, in Ontario and other provinces, who object to the goods and services tax, but especially to the tax as it is applied to books.

The petitioners are appalled that Canada is one of the few countries if not the only country in the western world, that taxes the reading of books, magazines and newspapers.
One might expect such a law in a totalitarian state but not in a free democratic country like Canada where the printed word is one of the cornerstones of our freedom and where magazines and newspapers and freedom of the press are considered one of our great freedoms and indeed, a very important freedom in Canada.
These petitioners call upon Parliament to repeal the goods and services tax in so far as it applies to publications. I am pleased to support and present this petition.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to introduce a petition on behalf of many people in the Stewiacke, Nova Scotia area.
The petitioners request that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police be vested with the statutory authority to enforce all existing and future safety regulations and provisions under the Railway Safety Act where currently they have no power or authorization to investigate or intervene on behalf of the citizens when a breach of the said act is committed.
This petition results from a series of accidents at the railway crossing at Stewiacke. The people there are most concerned that the provision is not properly enforced, in their opinion. Perhaps this petition will help get that enforcement.

As you know, Mr. Speaker, the communist authorities of Vietnam vowed during the seventh congress of the communist party that it will use all means necessary to maintain the power of the party.
Some of my constituents, Canadians of Vietnamese origin, have signed petitions calling on the government first, to encourage and pressure the Vietnamese government to abandon its inhumane policies and restore civil and humane rights in Vietnam; second, that all Vietnamese regulations, codes and constitutional provisions prohibiting free expression or denying freedom of association or religious freedom be eliminated; and finally, that the Vietnamese government and the communist party of Vietnam make a formal commitment to permit free and fair elections under international supervision so that the citizens of the country may determine the future leadership and orientation of their government.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
Debate is on all the motions that have just been moved.

Government Orders
[English)

Mr. Speaker, the pressure from the government has given us 10 minutes to debate 15 motions and these motions cover some of the most important points of difference.
The great majority of the 40-odd groups that appeared before our committee was opposed to the harsh restrictions placed on the entry of people into Canada to claim refugee status, restrictions harsher than in the previous law. I have several motions dealing with this but I probably will not be able to deal with all of them in 10 minutes, let alone with the ones from the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace. I would say I do support the motions from the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace as well.
My first motion, No. 23, is to replace part of clause 35 with these words: "unless an appeal from the order has been allowed"-that is an order to depart-"or unless the person satisfies an adjudicator, upon application, that there are good reasons why the claim"-that was the refugee claim-"was not made prior to the issuance of the removal order, and that the claim is not obviously unfounded".
I am trying to plug a hole in the process created by the government's abolishing the requirement that when the person who might be a refugee claimant comes to an inquiry, he be asked: Do you wish to make a refugee claim? That is in the present law. That has been crossed out, abolished.
There is a danger that a genuine refugee claimant will not know at what point he should say that he is a refugee or a refugee claimant, or that he is afraid of persecution if he returns. He might talk about things that happened back home but not clearly say that he is afraid of persecution and he may never be considered to have made a refugee claim.
I have asked in the motion that that hole be filled with this requirement, that if he does say he is a refugee and if at some later stage he explains why he did not make it at the beginning as required-because he was not asked- that he be allowed to proceed with the claim.
Motion No. 24 would add in: "A person who expresses a fear of persecution shall be advised by the immigration officer of the availability of the refugee determination process". This addresses the same point in a different way. If an immigration officer understands that a person has expressed a fear of persecution the officer has the
duty to tell him what the steps are by which he can apply to have that claim properly adjudged.
Motion No. 25 is a clause that sends a person back to a country through which he passed where he can be returned, a so-called safe country, of which the government proposes to make a list. It says he can be sent back if it is a country to which he can be returned. Then I wish to add these words: "and where the person can remain".
Countries have sometimes accepted a refugee claimant back and then shipped him on to the country he originally fled from. It has to be a country where the person can remain and it shall not be done unless the person satisfies the refugee division that the person has a well-founded fear of persecution in that country.
In other words, the person claims that he is afraid. If he is a Sri Lankan or a black African and is afraid to go back to Germany because of the race riots there, that should not be adjudged by the senior immigration officer at the border. The senior immigration officer should send that question for decision by the body that is specially trained, specially appointed and empowered to adjudge that question: the refugee division of the Immigration and Refugee Board.
I will skip Motion No. 26 and go on to Motion No. 27. Again this is to describe the country to which Canada intends to send a person back on the grounds that he should make and should have made a refugee claim there. Some countries have a very sloppy, superficial treatment of refugees partly because they do not have the money-very poor countries-or partly because they do not agree that much with it.
This is to be a country in the words I have here: "that has undertaken by means of a bilateral agreement with Canada or by means of a multilateral agreement to readmit and determine the refugee claims of persons who are returned to its territory from Canada". It is not enough to readmit him; they have to agree to determine the refugee claims.
Skipping Motion No. 28, I will go to Motion No. 29. This deals with a person who had decided in Canada not to be a refugee, had left the country and then came back again. The question is: Does he have reason to come back that he was considered not to have the first time he came? My motion inserts the words: "If that person has been decided by a competent person or body not to be a convention refugee or not to be eligible to have the claim determined by the refugee division, he can be sent away, unless the person can satisfy the refugee division that
November 23, 1992

there has been a change in circumstances which justifies a reconsideration of the original decision".
In Sri Lanka the Indian army came in and for two or three months and there was so-called peace. The refugee board decided it was all right to send Sri Lankans back to Sri Lanka. War broke out again and the refugee board would not send them back then, or almost none of them, during that war time. The circumstances had changed. That should be available to a person who went out and came back again, if he can convince the board, not the officer at the border, but the expert refugee board is the one that should be convinced of that and the officer should send him there.
Motion No. 64 would substitute on page 102 a much better approach for making these bilateral agreements. 1 am going to read it, although I might run out of time: "The minister, with the approval of the Governor in Council, may, subject to ratification in accordance with subsection (2), enter into these agreements"-that is, for burden sharing, for sharing the work of supporting, examining and perhaps entertaining refugees and the ratification that is required". Subsection (2) reads: "The Minister of Employment and Immigration shall lay or cause to be laid before each House of Parliament, for ratification, at least 60 sitting days before its effective date, every agreement that is proposed to be entered into under subsection (1), and it shall stand referred to such committees as may be designated or established by each House of Parliament".
The question of whether a country such as Germany is fit to have black refugee claimants returned there is a matter that should be debated within this House and not just done behind the closed doors of cabinet. That is the purpose of this motion.
Motion No. 67 is a motion to describe countries that we consider adequate with their refugee policy. It would amend clause 102 by inserting these words: "Countries that are parties to and comply with their obligations under the convention and international human rights law"-which goes far beyond the convention in many ways-"and that have agreed to accept back on their territory persons who came to Canada through that

country, and to ensure that those persons will have their refugee claims fully determined, and if accepted as refugees have all the rights afforded under the convention". That is a very complete definition which I think we should be using.
Finally Motion No. 71 concerns countries from which the refugee might have come, or claims to have come: "The Governor in Council shall only prescribe a country under paragraph (l)(s) or renew any prescription under that paragraph for that country if; (a) the country ensures respect for human rights of refugees and refugee claimants as established by the convention and international human rights law; (b) has instituted a procedure to identify and protect the convention refugees which meets the standards set by the executive committee of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees"-by the way Canada is on the executive of the High Commission for Refugees-"(c) has undertaken by international agreement or otherwise to readmit and determine the refugee claims of persons returning to its territory by Canada".

Mr. Speaker, I am going to talk to Motions Nos. 31, 36 and 34 and 66 which are amendments I put forward on behalf of the Liberal Party.
Under the present law, there is a two-stage process for admitting refugees to this country. At the first stage they determine questions of eligibility to proceed to a full hearing before the refugee board and they deal with questions of credibility.
The overwhelming number of experts in this field and the overwhelming number of witnesses who came before committee agreed with the government's move to get rid of the first stage hearing because a great percentage of the cases that went to the first stage hearing were agreed to and went on to the second stage. Therefore it was a waste of time and a waste of resources.
However, it was our view if you get rid of the first-stage hearing dealing with eligibility that you transfer those matters to the full hearing of the board as a preliminary question. You do that before the board

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
because there is due process before the board. There is a right to representation, the right to interpretation and so on.
Elowever that is not what the government has done in Bill C-86. It got rid of the first stage hearing dealing with questions of eligibility where there was due process and the right to a lawyer and so on. But it has given the decision making on eligibility to a senior immigration officer, to an official who will make a decision on these matters. This will be done without any due process, without any right to be heard by the refugee applicant, without any lawyer or any interpreter or whatever. He will make a decision just by looking at paper.
We say that is absolutely wrong. In effect, what the government is doing in Bill C-86 is placing a barrier between the refugee applicant and the refugee board where his case will be heard because it will allow, under Bill C-86, a senior immigration officer to turn away certain refugee applicants on the basis of five criteria. This is one of the principal objections to this bill.
Here we are, a signatory to the Geneva convention where we agree to accept refugees who are fleeing from countries of persecution and so on, but we are not giving them a right to be heard in all cases. We are giving a senior immigration officer the right to turn them away without a hearing and without due process which is against the legal traditions of this country.
In my amendment I am saying that one of the grounds on which the senior immigration officer can turn the applicant away is if the senior immigration officer believes that the applicant has been recognized as a refugee in another country. The government is saying that it is a black and white issue. There is no need for a hearing.
That is nonsense. All the experts before us have said it is not a black and white issue. Very often refugees come from one country. They flee into a neighbouring country. They stay there for a few weeks or a few days, maybe in a refugee camp. They get fed, clothed and many live in a tent, and then they go on maybe to Europe and finally come to Canada. The question as to whether they are recognized as refugees in those countries is a very difficult and complex one. Many countries do not have very clear-cut processes as we have in Canada which
finally do say: "Yes, you are a refugee" or "No, you are not a refugee".
We believe that that issue should not be left to a senior immigration officer who can decide that without any hearing or right to be heard. What we are saying in Motion No. 31 is that in that particular case, there would be referral for a hearing and the senior immigration officer would have to inform the refugee applicant of such a hearing especially where he or she would qualify under section 53. Section 53 is an exception to that rule, that where the person's life or freedom would be threatened for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership in a particular social group or for political opinion, should be allowed to stay in this country and not sent back to one of those countries, even if that person was recognized as a refugee in those countries. The other thing we are saying is that the senior immigration officer should refer those cases for a hearing when there is some doubt as to whether the applicant is eligible or not.
Another reason or the major criterion on which the senior immigration officer can turn people away is if the senior immigration officer believes that the applicant comes from what is called a safe third country. We say that the definition of a safe third country is too narrow. We totally agree with the report of the Senate committee. The Senate did a pre-study of this bill and with a Conservative majority and with the Conservative chairman, Senator Kinsella, they criticized the safe country provision on the following grounds.
They said that in order to return a person to a safe third country there must be a bilateral or multilateral agreement specifying which state is responsible for examining a refugee claim. It should be a precondition that we have either a bilateral or multilateral agreement with other countries so that they will treat people who are returned to them in a fair and judicial way. They go on to say that the country to which we return individuals must comply with the total convention relating to the status of refugees and not just simply article 33, as is provided for in Bill C-86.
In other words, we do not return the person to that third country unless we have a convention with that country. That country must agree with the entire international convention on refugees, and finally that country must have a refugee determination system equivalent to
November 23, 1992

the Canadian system that complies with Canadian principles of fundamental justice.
We are saying in these amendments that there must be due process in the decision with respect to eligibility and if we are going to return people to a safe third country, the safe third country must be defined in the way that was set out in the Senate report. Our amendments are totally in accordance with the Senate pre-study report. We are also saying that there must be greater access to section 53 which would prevent an applicant from being returned to another country where that person's life or freedom would be threatened for reasons of race, religion, nationality or membership in a particular party or social group.

Mr. Speaker, I just want to make some short remarks in support of the amendments by my colleague from Notre-Dame-de-Grace. From time to time in Toronto we are experiencing a situation where many of our public servants who are dealing with these immigration matters at the border crossing are telling us that they are so overworked that there is absolutely no way that they cope with the workload that is put on them. At times we have had situations where their stress has caused a reaction which has not served the process or the spirit of our refugee system very well. We have always had the judicial process to rely on.
It is not only wrong to leave this decision to the bureaucrat or to the official in charge, it is also unfair because we are putting them in a position where their judgment from time to time can be clouded. It is not a question of us saying that people should not be deported if they constitute a threat to the security of Canada. That is sometimes the position that is being presented to us by opposition, that we are just opening our doors to anyone and everyone.
There is a fine line. We are taking a very strong stand on anyone who is a threat to security or someone who has a criminal record. It is very important that this amendment be supported to make sure that we keep our judicial process in place.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to reply on this grouping of amendments. It is important though to point out first, and I know my friend from Trinity-Spadina did not
Government Orders
really mean this, that to suggest that there is anything the government has done in terms of the allocation of time that each speaker has in this debate, or the grouping of the amendments. This of course is not the case.
Those are the rules of the House and they have nothing to do with time allocation or anything else. That is the way this process works. I am sure he did not really mean to suggest that the government had caused him to have only 10 minutes or that the government had grouped these amendments. That simply is not the fact. I know he would want me to correct that impression which has been left.
Both my colleagues, the members for Trinity-Spadina and Notre-Dame-de-Grace, have rightly said that this group of amendments addresses a very important section of this piece of legislation.
As has been pointed out there was much concern around the two levels of hearings. The suggestion was that the first level be removed.
What is left though is obviously the concern that the process allows, as it must, for the question of determining eligibility.
The legislation provides that the senior immigration officer must be able to say to anybody who claims refugee status that they have access to the refugee determination system unless five conditions exist. Without going into detail, the primary concern is whether that refugee has found the protection he or she seeks in another country and whether that refugee in coming to Canada is bringing with him or her something that will provide a threat to the security of the country, a serious offence.
What has been very clear from the evidence in the committee is that if the senior immigration officer cannot simply and clearly show that the refugee applicant is breaking one of those five conditions then the refugee applicant has access to the determination system.
Quite simply put, if the applicant is not ineligible he or she is eligible. It is not a question of discretion. It is not a question of judgment. It is the obligation of the senior immigration officer, or in one case it gets referred to an adjudicator, to be able to show that this person is a convention refugee or has come from a country where protection is provided or has committed serious offences.

Government Orders
The second concept that we must deal with is the question of shared responsibility. Canada's very strong history in this area is such that we have become a very favoured nation. I think it is something we should be proud of and that we need to encourage. However, we also must recognize at a time when the number of refugees around this world is increasing that we all, particularly in the west or the north, in the industrialized world, have a responsibility.
It is incumbent upon us collectively to work to ensure, through the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, that we have a system in place that can deal with refugees.
An added burden of responsibility falls on Canada. We have to lead the rest of the world to the level of fairness and equity in our determination system. This process of shared responsibility, formally signing agreements, will increase the responsibility of other countries. That is particularly important.
Without going into the specifics of all of these motions, because a number of them come together, it is very important to recognize what section 53 of the legislation does. It is known as the non-refoulement provision. That says that we cannot send people back to a country where their freedom is threatened.
If we are in a position where perhaps that exists, section 53 says that a refugee shall not:
be removed from Canada to a country where the person's life or
freedom would be threatened for reasons of race, religion,
nationality, membership in a particular social group or political
opinion unless
It cannot happen. There are two exceptions. They are people described as inadmissible under paragraph 19(l)(c). It also refers to paragraph 19(l)(e), (f), (g), (j), (k), or (1), which involves security for the most part.
There is an added provision, which is that if that question arises the minister must show that the person constitutes a danger to the public in Canada. That is a condition that says that there may be reasons to remove them but they can only be removed under certain conditions and if they are a threat to Canada and the place to which they are removed will offer them the protection that is important.
I remind members again that there has long been a discussion about the charter. Many people do not agree
with this, and to me it is very fundamental. The charter governs how governments relate to people. The charter says that the Government of Canada must apply its laws to people whether they are in this country or outside. Some have argued that the charter should not apply unless one is physically in Canada. Some would argue that the charter should not apply unless a person is a landed immigrant. Some would argue that the charter should not apply unless the person is a citizen of this country.
I reject all of those positions fundamentally. The bill reflects that. The mood of the people who came before us reflected that the charter should apply to anybody who Canada deals with anywhere, that we cannot make decisions based on race, on nationality, country of origin or ethnicity. To do so would be fundamentally wrong.
Without addressing the specifics of all of these amendments I have addressed most of them in terms of their intent and what they deal with.

Finally, Motion No. 57 provides for an appeal or a review of any decision of the Immigration and Refugee Board that is based on questions of fact or questions of error.
For years now, ever since the Immigration and Refugee Board was set up, churches, NGOs, lawyers, experts who work with immigrants and refugees have said there must be an appeal process on the substance. The government has never agreed to that, although there have been many bad decisions. In every other area of life where the courts are involved or where there are quasi-judicial bodies, there are always appeals.
The government has allowed an appeal in law and that appeal on law can go to the Federal Court and right up to the Supreme Court of Canada in some cases, but it has never allowed an appeal on the facts, on the substance of the case, and we say that is wrong.
It is impossible for a system to be perfect and when you are dealing with human lives, with people fleeing from oppression, people who are fleeing from totalitarian governments, from civil wars such as in Yugoslavia or Somalia, or some of the situations that took place in Latin America, you cannot put these lives in danger. You simply do not have a system which provides for a corrective process, a review process.
In our amendment, amendment 57, we are saying there can be a review of a decision of the Immigration and Refugee Board in which the chairman orders such a review when there is new evidence that was not before the board in the first place, when it has been determined some of the evidence was wrong, or in general when there has been an error in the decision that was made. These are questions of fact, not questions of law, and we believe very strongly that there should be an appeal there as well.
The three matters before the House now as far as the Liberal Party is concerned are, first, that all questions of eligibility should be finally decided by the Immigration and Refugee Board, not by senior immigration officers.

Second, there should be no requirement for a unanimous decision of the board. The present system in which only one out of two is sufficient should remain. Third, there should be a review or an appeal process on the substance of our refugee system.

Mr. Speaker, I wish to deal with my five motions here. I want to deal with four of them very quickly and on the three motions of the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace, my party and I are in agreement with him.
Motion No. 48 is extremely important because of what I mentioned before about the gap at the border. It is lovely if the refugee gets to section 53, which the hon. member for St. John's East mentioned, but how does he get there? That was not clear in the discussions we had in committee. It may be clear to the government but it is not clear to me and to a lot of the public.
Until about seven years ago lawyers were allowed to meet potential clients right at the border, for example at Pearson Airport, and assist them while they had their first examinations by immigration officers. This government stopped that six or seven years ago. Now people are examined by an immigration officer and perhaps by a senior immigration office who takes notes which can be used against that person later on. However, that person has no witness, let alone legal advice.
We raised this question with the government and it said of course they will be allowed to have legal counsel if it is available. That has not been put in writing anywhere, except that it is recorded in the transcript of the meeting.
The government said it was going to change the regulations it adopted seven years ago which prevented lawyers from having access to any person arriving to enter Canada.
My party and I want to write in section 48 that in any proceeding before an immigration officer or a senior immigration officer, a person who claims to be a convention refugee may be represented by a barrister, solicitor or other counsel. This is a need that has been confirmed by the experience of not having that opportunity. No longer will the person have legal counsel provided by the federal government. That is abolished. I am not raising that issue. I am saying that if a lawyer is there, he or she should be able to assist the refugee claimant at the very first interview, not farther down the road when there

could be a dispute about what was said or whether the questions were properly asked.
Motion No. 49 concerns whether the hearing will be held in camera. The government has met us part way on this, saying that it will be in camera if it can be shown that there is any danger. It will be in camera unless there is an application to make it public. In that case, if the claimant can show that there is danger to the claimant or other persons, it should not be held in public.
There is a further need that was in the previous law. They should also be satisfied that the conduct at the proceedings in public would not impede the subject of the proceedings. That is the refugee claimant; he or she is the subject. When she is the subject it is even more important because many female refugee claimants have had dreadful experiences getting through borders to get to Canada. Because of cultural taboos which are stronger in some places than others, they find it very hard to tell what was done to them as women in such and such a place, even to an officer, let alone to a battery of journalists or other strangers.
Therefore it has been found that they sometimes fail to tell what has happened and that seriously damages their credibility later on, even though it was true. I want it in here that it will not impede the subject of the proceedings and no member of that person's family would be adversely affected. It is impeding the subject that we need to get in there.
Motions Nos. 50 and 51 refer to the minister's intervention. Motion No. 50 would delete what is at present at the bottom of page 68: "That the panel may, if it considers it appropriate to do so, give the minister a reasonable opportunity to question the person making the claim and any other witnesses, and to make representations concerning the claim".
I believe that is highly improper when the whole basis of the hearing was that it should be non-adversarial. This is not a criminal; we are not talking about proof, for proof is almost impossible to get from the old country at these hearings. We are talking about trying to find out whether the person has a claim, and to cross-examine
him in an adversarial way, as has sometimes happened in a minister's intervention through his deputy, is perhaps necessary in certain cases, which I will deal with, but as a generality is grossly unfair to the refugee claimant.
Coming now to Motion No. 51, I would like to see it reworded if it can be agreed that: "The Board may, if it considers it that legal issues of general importance, including issues of constitutional interpretation, application or validity, are raised in the proceedings, may give the minister an opportunity".
In other words, it is to limit the occasion in which the minister, through an adversarial prosecuting attorney approach, can cross-examine the claimant.
Finally, I want to deal with my motion, Motion No. 52, which I consider, in the light of the many deputations that we have heard to which the member for St. John's East has referred, perhaps the most important one apart from the questions of eligibility at the border.
If they do not get to the Immigration and Refugee Board, this question does not arise. If they do get to the Immigration and Refugee Board, the key issue is that it has been experience now that certain refugee claimants were rejected by the IRB and later it was found that there was information, maybe old information, which did not come to light in this country, or information based on changed country circumstances. It was not available in any documented form; for example, a warrant for arrest, which was not available at the time of the hearing.
As I mentioned before, the war in Sri Lanka, which ended when the Indian army intervened and then broke out again within two or three months, is still going on two or three years later.
My motion is:
(7) Notwithstanding any other provision of this act, if the Chairperson is satisfied that:
(a)	sufficient new evidence exists which was not available at the time of the Refugee Division hearing, or
(b)	conditions in the country of origin, or of habitual residence, as the case may be, have so changed, such that a different decision by the Refugee Division might be warranted, the Chairman may cause a new hearing of the claim to be held.

This does not increase the appeals to the courts, which have been a matter of concern on the government's side; overloading the courts and perhaps causing delays. This might cause a delay but of a very limited sort since it is not an adversarial type of hearing; it is an inquiry into the person's status, whether or not he or she is a refugee.
The chairman has the responsibility under this motion, if it is adopted, to be satisfied that there is reason to reopen or to have cause for a new hearing of the claim to be held.
I want to quote just one example from one of the witnesses who had documented many cases, about 50 cases out of 100 or more, that the vigil group examined; 50 cases it felt should have been re-examined. In one of six examples it gave us, it said: "Mr. E. is a Sri Lankan Tamil who fled Sri Lanka in 1989 after two of his friends were killed for providing equipment to the Tamil Tigers. He too had unwillingly given equipment to the Tigers and feared for his life. From 1974 to 1989, Mr. E. had been detained and repeatedly tortured brutally by the Sri Lankan army and the Indian peacekeeping forces. On the occasion, he was also detained by the Tigers. As a result of this treatment, Mr. E. continues to have flash-backs of his experiences of torture. He suffers from insomnia, nightmares, digestive problems and anxiety. The Immigration and Refugee Board refused Mr. E. because it misunderstood his testimony and believed he only feared the Indian army which had left the country. It gave no recognition to the cumulative effect of the numerous detentions and extreme persecution that Mr. E. endured at the hands of various armies, especially the Sri Lankan army which is still engaged in the bitter civil war against the Tigers".
If any such evidence should be brought before the chairman, I hope this Parliament would allow the chairman to use his judgment to reopen the case.

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Reid (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
Mr. Chairman, I would like first to comment on the three motions of my friend from Notre-Dame-de-Grace. The first motion, No. 38, deals with the fact that all eligibility hearings be referred to the IRB. Motion No. 54 deals
Government Orders
with what has come to be known as the split decision question. The third motion is the question of appeals.
I talked earlier about the senior immigration officer and his responsibilities in determining eligibility for access to the system. What the senior immigration officer does not do is deal with the credibility of the case. He does not talk about the nature of persecution. He would not talk about whether this person is a refugee or would have a valid refugee claim. The two levels of hearings are something we have tried to move away from because of the pressure it puts on the refugee claimants. We also have the problem of the pressure that it puts on the system and that in turn impacts on our ability to respond judiciously and quickly.
The question of the split decision, as it is referred to, has caused some concern and we have had a lot of discussion about it. Quite clearly it is one that responds to a current situation that has created concern in a number of areas.
The area that has created most debate and has worried most of us more than any other is the question that applies to documents. There is a misconception abroad that if anybody arrives with false documents or no documents, they automatically are in a position in which they must have a unanimous decision, remembering that in our system today if you appear before two members of the IRB and one says that you have a valid claim then that claim is accepted.
What the legislation says is that if you were in possession of documents-and remember we have amended it to respond to the some of the concerns-and you destroyed those documents without good reason, you will then need two people, not one, on the board saying that you have a legitimate claim. It is not whether you have false documents, it is not whether you have destroyed your documents for good reason, it is not whether you somehow got on a plane with no documents; rather, it is that you had the documents, you destroyed the documents and you had no good reason for doing so.
For those of us for whom that was a great concern in the beginning, this goes a long way in addressing that problem. The documents had to have been in the person's possession and they had to have been destroyed.

Government Orders
On the question of appeal, the law today does not allow for appeals on anything but questions of law. The question therefore is what do we do about it if we need to do anything about it?
I think it was Dr. Guy Goodwin-Gill who came before the committee and said: "Be careful now if you start getting into appeals on the basis of fact. What you end up with is a first level system that is not as responsible and as thorough as it should be, not that that is wanton or willing. It happens, it is human nature".
Clearly the process of appealing in law continues and is to be provided for in a different court but it is still there.
What is important and in my view a very major step is that the government has said that it understands that the process of appealing on humanitarian and compassionate grounds has not been effective. I would argue that is exactly the case, that it needs to be visible and that there needs to be real criteria against which people can measure what they do and how successful they can or cannot be.
As a result, the government has asked the former first chair of the IRB, Mr. Gordon Fairweather, earlier a member of this institution, to set up the regulations on this. They will consult on that process as well so that we do have an H and C process, as we call it, humanitarian and compassionate grounds, that is visible.
All of us who deal with refugees who appeal under the H and C provisions do not know what we are shooting at, do not know what the targets are, do not know what criteria the case that we present will be judged against. I think that is important.
It is important as well in a couple of other provisions, not the least of which is the one covered in Motion No. 52 by my friend from Trinity-Spadina, where he talks about changed circumstances.
We discussed earlier a proposed amendment that dealt with a 12-month ban for reapplying. I pointed out at that time it does not apply to refugees. Someone can come back in 90 days. However, in the interim, it is important to recognize that the humanitarian and compassionate provisions will provide for and take into account the questions of changed circumstance.
Most of the early discussions or arguments or debates I had with the IRB were over changed circumstances. We had to apply these against humanitarian and compassionate grounds. It has been very difficult. We have not been successful in that area. My friend is right in pointing out that we must take into account changed circumstances, not changed circumstances in Canada or necessarily with the refugee, but particularly how that refugee relates back to changed circumstances in his or her country.
I want very quickly to comment on his proposal in Motion No. 51. I am not sure I completely understand this section about the minister appearing, particularly when we are dealing with big legal issues. I would think that the answer is that we would want some of these big cases that deal on those issues discussed in a court where perhaps it is more appropriate.
One of the problems we have with confidentiality is what is known as the Pacific Press case. We are not particularly happy with the amendment we brought forward because it is not complete. My friend from Trinity-Spadina is right when he says that the ability to have a confidential hearing is something that needs to be protected. For the refugee, it needs to be protected. For the refugee's family, it needs to be protected. For those that are left behind, it needs to be protected. Obviously if someone has fled their homeland, they are fleeing persecution and that condition continues.
The government has gone as far as it can in recognizing the decision of Pacific Press which says that the media should have access.
The assumption is that the cases will be closed, however, if there is an application to the IRB, then a decision is to be taken.
The initial government proposal under Bill C-86 was that they would not be closed. That was unacceptable for a lot of reasons. The amendment that was brought forward in the committee was an attempt to find a balance between the judgment of the court and a desire to keep the hearings confidential.

Mr. Speaker, these three amendments put forward by the Liberal Party have to do with appointments to the board. The first two amendments would have appointments to the board limited to five years. Bill C-86 provides that the appointment of the chairman and the board members can be for up to seven years. Considering the government's record with these appointments we do not think that is acceptable.
The other amendment is one which would require all nominees for appointment to the Immigration and Refugee Board be approved by the Standing Committee on Employment and Immigration.
November 23, 1992

Why are we making these two proposals? We are making these proposals because the majority of appointments to the Immigration and Refugee Board have been too political. They have been for individuals who are unfamiliar with immigration and refugee matters. As a matter of fact, they are not only unfamiliar but insensitive to immigration and refugee matters. There have been some, what I would call, horror stories with respect to incidents happening before the board.
It is true that in Bill C-86 the government is giving the chairman certain authority to discipline members of the board who do not carry out their functions properly or who misbehave, but we do not think that is enough.
We had incidents last winter where members of the board ridiculed claimants before the board, laughed at them, made fun of their cases. We had other incidents where members of the board fell asleep while refugee applicants were making their cases. Recently a member of the board resigned because of what he called widespread racism among certain members of the board.
I acknowledge immediately that there have been some very good appointments to the board. I give credit to the past chairman of the board, Mr. Fairweather. Although he was a Conservative member of this House, he was an outstanding appointment and did a good job; but he was not responsible for the appointments.
As I say some of these appointments were very ill advised. As a matter of fact they proved to be an embarrassment to the government. The most recent one is the case where a member resigned and stated that he resigned because he felt there was widespread racism with respect to certain members of the board and he could not work in that atmosphere.
We propose two things: First, that the appointments of the chairperson and of members be limited to five years. We feel five years is enough. It gives them enough time to develop in their work, but on the other hand it is not too long if they are bad appointments. Second, we are suggesting that with appointments of this kind, as I said earlier in this debate, people are dealing with questions of life and death with respect to people fleeing from countries of oppression. If the wrong decision is made or
Government Orders
if this is not taken seriously, they could be returned to countries where they would be imprisoned or would even be killed.
We have recommended something similar to what they do in the United States where senior appointments are approved by committees of Congress. We are suggesting that the appointments be approved by the Standing Committee on Labour, Employment and Immigration.
That may not be the best answer, but it will be an improvement over what is presently in place where the government unilaterally and without any consultation makes these appointments and too many of them have been bad. There might be other methods of reviewing appointments.
A few years ago when the Liberal Party was in government we set up a system for reviewing appointments to the bench with the Canadian Bar Association. There might be a better way of getting approval for individuals to be appointed to the Immigration and Refugee Board. I was hoping that my amendment would push or press the government to come up with a better answer, but it has not. It is quite content to continue along the lines it has already proceeded so I am putting my amendment that these appointments must be subject to approval by the parliamentary committee.
One must remember that the government has a majority of members on these committees, but the very fact that the appointment would have to be reviewed would deter the government from making silly appointments as it has done from time to time. I think it would encourage the government to make better appointments knowing that those appointments would have to be reviewed publicly.
There are the three amendments. The purpose of them is to improve appointments to the Immigration and Refugee Board.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak in favour of these three amendments. I listened very carefully to my colleague, our critic for immigration. He made excellent points, but I want to reiterate them as a member from metropolitan Toronto who has had many people come into his riding office over the last four years to complain about the nature of the

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
process and how their claims were being dealt with, particularly by the people listening to the claims.
I note one of the amendments would limit the appointment of the chairperson from seven to five years. I think that is a very good idea. There is no demonstrable reason to have an appointment for seven years. In other appointments such as the chairman of the National Parole Board we have all kinds of different things. There is no reason to have them appointed for beyond a period of five years.
That is also coincidentally the maximum mandate of a particular government. It only makes sense that when there is a change of government there might be a change of focus, there might be a change of approach, and therefore there might be a need to change a particular person, in this case the chairperson.
However, my colleagues were being charitable in connection with the length of time that members can be appointed. Five years is exceedingly generous, never mind seven years. However that is fine. It is better to be generous than not so. Certainly the chairperson must be there for a period of time to establish a stamp of his or her own method of operating the particular department.
What is most important it seems to me in this triplicate of amendments is this notion that we get the people involved through the Parliament of Canada. How do we do that? By getting the House of Commons standing committee involved.
It is a very reasonable proposal. We have just recently seen over the last little while in 1992 how the United States has a situation where various appointees can be examined and can in fact be turned down depending on the rationale. That is not so much the point because we are not going a witch-hunt in committee. Anybody brought forward as a proposed person by the government is not automatically going to be wrong. No, on the contrary.
It is to give Canadians and the people who are involved with that particular system-the lawyers, the refugee claimants and the various other people-a sense of empowerment if I can put it that way. Canadians feel they are not empowered. They feel that too many things are being decided without their input.
Another perfect example is the Governor in Council. Who is that? That is the Prime Minister. He is going to make all these appointments. Nobody is going to be consulted, at least no one in terms of what the ordinary Canadian on the street can possibly understand to be a person who would be consulted. No, it is going to be the Prime Minister making decisions.
If we bring this matter before the House of Commons through one of its committees, it gives Canadians an opportunity to feel that their government is open, is not hiding things, is not subject to patronage. Rather it welcomes the opportunity to have the impact and input of Canadians on who these people will be.
I hear all sorts of dinosauric grumblings on the government side because they do not want openness. They are perfectly willing to have their little patronage plums and have people hand little gifts out for doing certain things for their party. We do not take that approach on this side. We think there should be more power in the House of Commons, not less power in the House of Commons. We think parliamentary committees should have more power, not less power.
We make a reasonable suggestion, a reasonable amendment in which we suggest the House of Commons committee review these appointments. We go one step further because we know there might be someone who would say it would be dragged on for political purposes. On the contrary, it says right in the amendment that in 30 days the decision has to be made.
It is interesting that there is all kinds of carping over there from various members, but I would be very surprised if any of them had the courage to stand up on their hind legs and tell us why this amendment was bad.
Precisely what is wrong with it? Why should Parliament and parliamentary committees not get involved in the political appointments that are presently being done behind closed doors? I challenge someone over there to get up and tell Canadians for householder use and for the next election, if necessary, that they should not be involved in the appointments to this board.

I commend the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace and the hon. member for Thunder Bay-Nipigon for bringing three well thought out amendments to this act which give people empowerment, which give Canadians the realistic belief that they are having some impact on what is going on behind closed doors in the Prime Minister's Office. I support the amendments whole-heartedly.
Mr. Speaker, in the interest of finishing our work before the deadline, all I have to say is that I support the three motions moved by the member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace.

Mr. Speaker, I will not take the full time allotted to me, but I just wanted to make an intervention after my colleague from Scarborough West and our critic from Notre-Dame-de-Grace made recommendations on these motions.
I should say at the outset that we had some discussion on our side as to whether the appointments should be made for the five-year period or the seven-year period as recommended by the government. These are some of the most highly sought appointments that any government can make.
I had opted for something less than five years. My colleague convinced me, with his wealth of experience and time spent on immigration matters, that five years was a good compromise between what we were proposing and what the Conservatives were proposing. Five years is a very long time, particularly when a bad appointment has been made and that person is kept on the bench, as I call it, for five years.
We have already seen some of those. There are very good appointments and f compliment the government for making them. Unfortunately there are some bad appointments. It is unfortunate there is not a mechanism within the structure so a bad appointment can be corrected immediately. Once a bad appointment is made, according to this particular statute there is very little that can be done about it. If we do not want the person that we are paying somewhere around $85,000 or $100,000 a year plus expenses for sitting on and hearing cases because he is not good at what he is doing, we must retain him and still continue to pay him. It is almost as if we have to remove him by way of a judicial hearing or
Government Orders
something approaching the judicial inquiry process on appointments to the bench.
I did not want to dwell too much on the length of time. We agree it should be shorter. However, I did want to mention the quality of the appointments and try to impress upon the government across that they are a little different from regular appointments made to different boards. These are people who are making quasi-judicial decisions concerning the future of people's lives.
As a result of these quasi-judicial decisions affecting the lives of people, they are considered to be statutory powers given to them under the act. As a result of the statutory interpretation of these powers, as my colleague knows, they are all subject to the rules of natural justice and at least to the doctrine of procedural fairness that is so necessary.
That is why it is so important for every appointment made in the future that these people be brought before the parliamentary committee so that we can test whether they have some knowledge of the rules of procedural fairness or the rules of natural justice. It is fundamental knowledge on behalf of these appointments that they should have an inherent knowledge of that particular legal framework. When we talk of the rules of procedural fairness we are talking about the fundamental rules of the right to have counsel present when one is making one's case, the permitting of a transcript to be made during the hearing, and the ability of the people who are calling the hearing to state their position prior to the hearing date so that the person making the application knows the case which he has to meet.
Other procedural requirements are the care that must be taken to make sure that those who make the decisions are those who hear the evidence. We have seen instances where those who have heard the evidence have not necessarily made the decisions. In the last six to eight months we have been able to see predetermined judgments where one fills in the blanks and that certainly flies in the face of procedural fairness or natural justice that should be afforded to every person pursuant to section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
I see my time is getting short. Our side believes that one thing we should be trying to do to stay out of the court system and the appeal process on these hearings that take a considerable amount of time is those persons who are going to be charged with the responsibility of hearing these cases should at least have some knowledge

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
of the rules of procedural fairness, some knowledge of the rules of natural justice so that when they are hearing these cases there can be no appeal if these cases are heard properly in the first instance.
I support this motion whole-heartedly. I hope that the government will reconsider its position and endorse this proposal and have every person who is considered to be or is under consideration to be a quasi-judicial officer for the immigration appeal board appear before an independent group of members of Parliament so that they can at least be questioned on those matters that are absolutely relevant to fairness in procedure on behalf of the cases that the refugees will be claiming to it.

To me, the key components or the key attributes for an appointment to the IRB should be first of all, compassion, second, common sense and third, enough intelligence and capacity to deal with the tremendous amount of work, the tremendous amount of pressure and the very confusing and often conflicting evidence that leads to a very difficult and sometimes very heart-wrenching decision.
In respect of that, the IRB has set up a very detailed and comprehensive process of training and education. It has developed a whole series of guidelines which help board members to make their decisions and has set in place a series of systems that will provide for review of performance and discipline where it is warranted and necessary.
As we look at Motion No. 43, we should recognize that yes, we can debate whether the chair should be there for five years or for seven years. I would argue that the chair
should be there for seven years to allow for the continuity that is important in order for the chair to become familiar not just with the day-to-day goings on, but the over-all direction of what the board does and to ensure that he or she can carry out the job efficiently in that time.
It is important to recognize that as is the case with normal board members, at any time the chair can be removed for cause. The Order in Council can be rescinded and the person can be removed from that position as can any board member if there is good reason to do so.
Now for the question of allowing the standing committee to review the appointments. I think one of my colleagues across the way mentioned how it may not be the right solution but it may not be a bad idea. I do not argue that it may not be a bad idea, but I agree that for us now in this piece of legislation to suggest that the tribunal appointments all of a sudden be reviewed by a standing committee would get us into a position that this bill would create a precedent that may not be suitable in relation to other legislation that does the same thing. As I said, I am not convinced that it is perhaps not a good idea to look at, but I would argue that to move this amendment now is not the thing to do.
As I look at the board that has operated in St. John's for the last number of years, the person that is seen I suppose as the chair, Lisa Gilad, has a background in immigration. She has written books on the process. The three people who are with her, one of whom has been transferred in from Stephenville, Jim Sparks, along with Tom Rideout and Tom Murphy have shown that their ability and willingness to work hard has led to the belief in many quarters in this country that one of the best places to have a hearing heard for fairness and equity is St. John's, Newfoundland. That is not something I am just saying. It is something the system recognizes because they have taken their jobs seriously and they conduct themselves very conscientiously. They have received the respect of the community because of the work they have done and, in particular, if I may say so, because of the leadership of Lisa Gilad.

He said: Mr. Speaker, this group of amendments is really only two amendments. One is Motion No. 58 amending the procedure for applying for a certain kind of appeal. The other really is amending the responsibility for appeals, but because of the rules of procedure we follow the second one has to be done five times, that is to say, deleting five clauses which are all essentially part of the same action.
Motion No. 58 is important because it would protect some of the rights of appeal not just by refugees but by anybody in Canada under any section of the Immigration Act. In other words, it affects Canadian citizens if they do not think they have been given the right decision about sponsoring a relative. It can affect a Canadian permanent resident. It can affect an ordinary immigrant and of course it can affect a refugee claimant.
What we have in the Canadian justice system generally is that a decision can be appealed. Even a convicted criminal has the right to appeal in case the judge may have made a mistake. However, the 1987 amendments to the Immigration Act very gravely restricted this appeal right for refugee claimants and immigrants and permanent residents and Canadian citizens, everybody in the country. It prohibited the appeal on the merits, that is to say an appeal to decide whether the Immigration and Refugee Board or any other body, adjudicator, even an immigration officer, had made a mistake about the facts. It permits only an application for a judicial review that is
to decide whether the decision maker failed to follow the lawfully required procedures.
This is quite unfair since refugee claimants, immigrants, Canadian permanent residents, Canadian citizens, as such, are not common criminals. They should not have fewer rights than common criminals. In particular refugees should not have fewer rights in a matter that could be a life-and-death decision for them.
Bill C-86 restricts this right still further by prohibiting an appeal of the decision of a judge of the Federal Court trial division. If a question has been appealed to the Federal Court and the appellant is not satisfied, he cannot appeal it unless the judge who gave the negative decision to him or her, while rendering the judgment has certified that a serious question of general importance is involved and the judge has stated that question.
That is ridiculous. Nowhere else in the Canadian justice system is the right to appeal made to depend on a judge saying that maybe he was wrong in the decision, and it is an important matter and an appeal to a higher court would be allowed. We are told it is done somewhere else, but nowhere in Canada.
Motion No. 58 would at least protect the universally existing right of the refugee claimant, immigrant, permanent resident or Canadian citizen to ask the Federal Court of Appeal to grant leave to appeal the lower court's decision.
That is the present law. The federal court can grant that.
What I would like to do with this motion is restore that right to refugees, to permanent residents, to citizens and to any immigrant as the case may be.
My motion is supported by the Canadian Bar Association, the Ontario Refugee Lawyers Association, and the Ontario Law Union. They all support this right to seek the leave of a higher court to appeal a lower court decision.
There are not many appeals now because each level of the court denies most of the applications it gets for judicial review. Therefore the courts can defend themselves from being overloaded. It is important in our Canadian, and British, system of justice that there be the possibility of a case going to a higher court and that it should not be so ridiculously restricted as it is by Bill
November 23, 1992

C-86 because the higher courts do have a responsibility for interpreting, evaluating and testing lower court decisions. That is the first action.
The second action concerns the other five motions. These five motions of the bill will further restrict the right of appeal in immigration matters at the time of transition from the present act to when the amended act comes into force. It will retroactively move cases that were before the court of appeal, at the earliest stage, back to the trial court. That means that instead of three experienced judges evaluating the work of a less experienced judge another less experienced judge will be evaluating the less experienced judge or perhaps even a newly appointed judge, appointed specifically for that purpose as is provided elsewhere in the act.
There is the further problem that the court of appeal at present has the power to set aside the decision of the lower court and substitute for it the decision of the court of appeal. That gives a final answer to the matter and saves time, trouble and uncertainty for everybody.
Bill C-86 takes away that power. By sending it back to another judge of the trial division it creates a situation in which the other judge can only say to the first judge: "Well, you were wrong, try it again". It leaves the matter dragging on, using up time and creating great uncertainty-
I am asking the House to restore that part of the right that the present act provides for appeal by permission of the court of appeal and to restore it for those who may be just acquiring that right but might lose it in the transition. It still does not give, under the Immigration Act, the rights that Canadians and all others in Canada enjoy in other matters but at least it would not take away the small right that they have now.

Mr. Speaker, I will be very brief. I support these amendments by my hon. colleague from Trinity-Spadina because, as he said, the grounds for appeal are already very limited. I spoke a few minutes ago in favour of an amendment that I was putting forward which would allow the chairman of the board to order a review of decisions of the board. That will be voted on later.

Here the hon. member for Spadina is dealing with the situation in which the judge of the federal court must produce a certificate before his own decision can be appealed. This is an unusual provision in Canadian law. Usually in Canadian law if someone wants to appeal to an appeal court they beg leave to appeal at that very appeal court. They ask it if they can appeal a lower court's judge and the higher court, the court of appeal, decides whether their case is subject to appeal to their court or not.
However, in Bill C-86 the government is saying: "You can only appeal to the higher court if the judge whose decision you do not like certifies that you can appeal his judgment", which is not the tradition of our legal system.
When we discussed this in committee the minister and his officials said: "They do something similar in one situation in Great Britain". They may in Great Britain in one situation but the general rule in Britain and Canada and in most democratic countries is that people apply for leave to appeal to the court of appeal. They do not ask the judge whose decision they do not like to provide a certificate saying that they can appeal his judgment. For these reasons I support the hon. member.
