He said: Mr. Speaker, these three motions, Motions Nos. 59, 60 and 61, concern transportation companies. In the 1978 bill there were penalties provided for transportation companies bringing in undocumented aliens. The penalties were greatly increased in size and scope in the 1987 amendments and they have been further increased in size and scope here.
Some of these motions were suggested by the representatives of the transportation companies, particularly air and sea transportation, who appeared before our committee.
The focus of this part of the bill is to attempt to discourage transportation companies from bringing in undocumented aliens, that is to say people who do not have a valid passport with a visa. The present act provides heavy penalties to the owners of ships, airplanes or vehicles that bring in these undocumented aliens if the owner and the employees fail to exercise due diligence in examining the passports and visas of members or in stopping stowaways. Bill C-86 would both
Government Orders
increase the size of the penalties and add an unfair procedure.
Motion No. 59 amends Bill C-86 by deleting lines 21 to 30 of clause 78. It requires that the transportation company either ensure that all passengers have the required documents from the time they embark until the time they are presented to the immigration officers in Canada, or else collect the documents and hold them for presentation with the passengers to the immigration officers.
This is an unreasonable requirement. It would put some ship agents, for example, right out of business. It is close to doing that under the present act but would do it more so under the proposed bill.
After all, false visas and passports which can be obtained for a price are being so well forged that even immigration officers sometimes get fooled. It is unfair to penalize transportation crews for not doing the immigration officer's specialized job better than the immigration officer himself may be able to do it.
The government did go part way by putting in the word knowingly. Transportation companies are at fault if they knowingly bring in an undocumented alien. That was a very good move which we strongly support, bringing it back to the wording that was used in the 1987 legislation. It still has an unfair procedure for penalizing them if it thinks that due diligence was not used; in other words that it was done knowingly.
In the second place the problem further is that the passport is the property of a foreign government and it is to be kept in the possession of the person who is identified by it. Ordering transportation crews to seize passports, with the visas in them, infringes the sovereignty of another government and ought not to be done without the express approval of that government.
Here is the sting: Motion No. 60 amends page 60 after line 33 by adding "notwithstanding this section, a transportation company is not liable to pay in respect of a person any administration fee for a period of more than six months after the date of entry of the person into Canada". This says that the matter cannot be dragged out for years and years, and then stick them with the fine.
The problem is that Motion No. 61 has to do with the power of the minister to take the fine out of the deposited money. The bill provides that the minister can require the transportation company to deposit the equivalent of money in an account, and then when the minister has decided that the company improperly allowed an undocumented alien to enter the country, the

November 23, 1992
Government Orders
deputy minister can order that the fine be taken out of that account. That is very convenient for the government; it does not have to do the work of going to court to prove that the transportation company was negligent in having allowed that undocumented alien to slip through. It just takes the money.
I suppose the transportation company can go to court and try to prove that the government was wrong in taking the money, but that is not the normal way of carrying on business, to take the money first and then have somebody else do the proving afterward. Shoot first and ask questions afterward is not in our Canadian tradition of justice.
Therefore, I ask that these three motions be adopted so as to restore a measure of fairness. I have not talked about the size of the fines, which are bigger, but I have simply requested a measure of procedural fairness for the transportation companies.

Mr. Speaker, we support these amendments. They are similar to ones that we presented in committee which would have alleviated the heavy burden that the government is putting on the transportation companies.
The government is applying very heavy penalties to the airlines and to the shipping companies even when these transportation companies use due diligence and do everything in their power to prevent illegal immigrants coming aboard their aeroplanes or ships. This does not seem fair. There are penalties now but this bill greatly increases the penalties.
The airline and shipping executives came to us and told us that they are at a period in their history when the airlines are going bankrupt all over the world, when their costs are exceedingly high and the government is putting this new burden on them at this time.
It is an interesting matter when the NDP and the Liberals are going to the support of the large airline companies which employ a lot of Canadians and provide a lot of employment and the bad Conservative government is putting a very heavy burden on them and shifting them closer to situations of financial impossibility.

The current act empowers companies to hold documents. As a transporter of people they are responsible for ensuring that if they bring those people to this country, those people have to be able to be accepted in this country.
